{{for|the Norwegian footballer|Joshua King (footballer)}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Joshua King |image = Joshua King by William Beechey.jpg |image_size = |caption = Joshua King by [[William Beechey]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1798|01|16|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Lowick, Cumbria|Lowick]], [[Ulverston]], [[Lancashire]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|1857|09|01|1798|01|16|df=y}} |death_place = President's Lodge, [[Queens' College, Cambridge]], England |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = |ethnicity = |field = |work_institutions = [[University of Cambridge]] |alma_mater = [[Queens' College, Cambridge]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = [[Smith's Prize]] (1819)
[[Senior Wrangler]]
[[Lucasian Professor of Mathematics]] |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Joshua King''' (16 January 1798 – 1 September 1857) was the [[Lucasian Professor of Mathematics]] at the [[University of Cambridge]] from 1839 to 1849.{{acad|id=KN814J|name=King, Joshua}} He was also the President of [[Queens' College, Cambridge]], from 1832 until his death and [[Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge University]] from 1833–4.{{cite web|url=http://www.queens.cam.ac.uk/life-at-queens/about-the-college/college-facts/fellows-and-presidents/fellows-1800-1899|title=Fellows 1800 – 1899|publisher=}} ==Education== Educated at [[Hawkshead Grammar School]], Joshua King went first to [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] in 1815 but moved to [[Queens' College, Cambridge|Queens' College]] in February 1816 as a sizar (i.e. a student receiving some financial assistance), and graduated [[Senior Wrangler]] in 1819. ==Career== He was elected a Fellow of the [[Queens' College, Cambridge|Queens’]] in 1820, and served as its President from 1832 to his death – the first person not in holy orders to be so elected. In the University, he was [[Lucasian Professor of Mathematics]] from 1839, resigning because of ill-health in 1849 having given no lectures and published only one paper. His interests seemingly shifted from mathematics to law and politics, although he declined to stand as [[Tory]] candidate for Parliament for either the town or the University. He served on many committees, and was Vice-Chancellor in 1833/34. He died on 1 September 1857 aged 59, and was buried in the antechapel of the College. :
"Joshua King came to Cambridge from [[Hawkshead Grammar School]]. It was soon evident that the school had produced someone of importance. He became [[Senior Wrangler]], and his reputation in Cambridge was immense. It was believed that nothing less than a second [[Isaac Newton|Newton]] had appeared. They expected his work as a mathematician to make an epoch in the science. At an early age he became president of [[Queens' College, Cambridge|Queens’]]; later, he was Lucasian Professor. He published nothing; in fact, he did no mathematical work. But as long as he kept his health, he was an active and prominent figure in Cambridge, and he maintained his enormous reputation. When he died, it was felt that the memory of such an extraordinary man should not be permitted to die out, and his papers should be published. So his papers were examined, and nothing whatever worth publishing was found."[http://www.queens.cam.ac.uk/page-510 Queens' College Record 2004] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100411225040/http://www.queens.cam.ac.uk/page-510 |date=April 11, 2010 }}

{{EngvarB|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Junior Stanislas | image = Junior Stanislas 2015.jpg | image_size = 175 | caption = Stanislas playing for [[AFC Bournemouth]] in 2015 | fullname = Felix Junior Stanislas<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|11|26|df=y}}<ref name="Sky Sports Football Yearbook 2012–2013">{{cite book|editor1-first=Glenda|editor1-last=Rollin|editor2-first=Jack|editor2-last=Rollin|title=Sky Sports Football Yearbook 2012–2013|year=2012|publisher=[[Headline Publishing Group|Headline]]|location=London|isbn=978-0-7553-6356-8|page=444|edition=43rd}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Kidbrooke]], England | height = {{convert|1.83|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/3766/Junior-Stanislas/overview|title = Junior Stanislas|accessdate = 11 December 2017|publisher = Premier League}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] | clubnumber = 19 | youthyears1 = 2000–2008 | youthclubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | years1 = 2008–2011 | clubs1 = [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] | caps1 = 42 | goals1 = 5 | years2 = 2008–2009 | clubs2 = → [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] (loan) | caps2 = 6 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2011–2014 | clubs3 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps3 = 93 | goals3 = 7 | years4 = 2014– | clubs4 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] | caps4 = 93 | goals4 = 17 | nationalyears1 = 2009 | nationalyears2 = 2009 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 08:02, 22 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Felix Junior Stanislas''' (born 26 November 1989), is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]].
He started his career in the youth team of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at the age of 10 in 2000. He signed a three-year academy contract in the summer of 2006, playing regularly for the under-18 side and reserves. In November 2008, he joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] on a six-week loan. He made his first-team debut for West Ham in March 2009, at the age of 19. He signed a three-and-a-half-year contract in April 2009.
In August 2011, he joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee. In June 2014 he signed for Bournemouth on a free transfer, helping them to the Championship title in his first season. In September 2018 he signed a contract extension with Bournemouth until 2021.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Perrett |first1=Neil |title=New deal for Stanislas |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/16695514.new-deal-for-stanislas/ |website=Daily Echo |accessdate=10 September 2018}}</ref>
==Club career== ===West Ham United=== Born in [[Kidbrooke]], London,<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas">{{cite web|url=http://www.whufc.com/page/PlayerProfilesDetail/0,,12562~43924,00.html |title=Player profile Junior Stanislas |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |accessdate=2010-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217040912/http://www.whufc.com/page/PlayerProfilesDetail/0%2C%2C12562~43924%2C00.html |archivedate=17 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> Stanislas first joined [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] as a schoolboy at the age of 10.<ref>[http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0,,12562~1606213,00.html England call for Stanislas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330212530/http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0%2C%2C12562~1606213%2C00.html |date=30 March 2009 }} West Ham United F.C.</ref> In May 2006, Stanislas signed a three-year academy scholarship. He made his [[Premier Academy League]] debut in a 3–2 defeat to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 8 April 2006, at the age of 16.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> He became a regular for the Academy in the [[2006–07 FA Premier Academy League|2006–07]] season, appearing 26 times and scoring 9 goals as West Ham finished as runners-up to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> He carried his goalscoring form into the [[2007–08 Premier Academy League|2007–08]] season, scoring 10 goals in 24 appearances. He made his [[Premier Reserve League]] debut on 29 August 2007, in a 2–1 defeat to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. His first goals came in the 8–0 rout over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], as he netted a brace.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> He was part of the first-team squad that travelled to North America in the summer of 2008 for the pre-season tour.<ref name="WEST HAM YOUNGSTER SIGNS">{{cite web|url=http://www.southendunited.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10444~1468549,00.html |title=WEST HAM YOUNGSTER SIGNS |publisher=Southend United F.C. |accessdate=2008-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090103003623/http://www.southendunited.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10444~1468549%2C00.html |archivedate= 3 January 2009 |df= }}</ref> He started the [[2008–09 Premier Reserve League|2008–09]] season in the reserves, scoring his first goal of the season on 21 October 2008, in a 1–0 home win over Arsenal.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/>
====Loan to Southend United==== On 27 November 2008, Stanislas joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] on loan for six weeks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stanislas joins Southend on loan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/s/southend_utd/7753023.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=27 November 2008}}</ref> He made an immediate impact on his professional debut, scoring a brace, including a spectacular free kick, against [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] in the [[FA Cup]] [[2008-09 FA Cup#Second Round Proper|second round]] on 29 November.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7741969.stm |title=Southend 3–1 Luton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 November 2008 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> His league debut came on 6 December in a 3–0 defeat, away at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester 3–0 Southend |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7752365.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=6 December 2008}}</ref> His first goal for Southend came on 26 December as he scored the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]], which brought to end a run of seven league games without victory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Southend 1–0 Northampton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7787745.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=26 December 2008}}</ref> He was part of the side that earned a memorable 1–1 draw with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] in the FA Cup third round.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea 1–1 Southend |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7803244.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=3 January 2009}}</ref> However, Southend could not repeat their heroics at [[Roots Hall]] as the Shrimpers lost 4–1 in the replay. Stanislas returned to West Ham on 19 January 2009, after a 3–1 defeat to [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] at [[Edgeley Park]].<ref>{{cite news|title=STANISLAS RETURNS TO WEST HAM |url=http://www.southendunited.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10444~1525055,00.html |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=19 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005194653/http://www.southendunited.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10444~1525055%2C00.html |archivedate= 5 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> He made a total of nine appearances in all competitions, scoring three goals.
====Return to West Ham==== Stanislas made his West Ham and [[Premier League]] debut on 16 March 2009 against bottom of the table [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], replacing [[Savio Nsereko]] in the second half.<ref>[http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0,,12562~1593005,00.html West Brom stifle Hammers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318041228/http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0%2C%2C12562~1593005%2C00.html |date=18 March 2009 }} West Ham United F.C.</ref> He scored his first goal on his first start for the club, in a 2–0 home win against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 4 April.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7972794.stm West Ham 2–0 Sunderland] BBC Sport</ref> On 9 April, he signed his first professional contract, a long-term four-and-a-half-year deal, lasting until the summer of 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stanislas signs new Hammers deal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/w/west_ham_utd/7993539.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=10 April 2009}}</ref> He had an extended run in the first-team when first choice midfielders [[Valon Behrami]] and [[Jack Collison]] were both out injured. On 24 May, the last game of the season, Stanislas scored the winner in the 2–1 win over [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], which sealed Boro's relegation to the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/middlesbrough/8066448.stm Southgate braced for player exits] BBC Sport</ref> He made a total of 9 appearances for West Ham, scoring 2 goals in the [[2008–09 West Ham United F.C. season|2008–09]] season.
[[File:Junior Stanislas.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Stanislas with West Ham in January 2010]] Stanislas started the [[2009–10 West Ham United F.C. season|2009–10]] season as a first team regular featuring in the first 5 games, including a 2–0 away win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. He also scored a brace in West Ham's 3–1 [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] [[2009–10 Football League Cup|second round]] victory over arch-rivals [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in August 2009. The first goal came three minutes from time before scoring a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]] winner in [[extra time]]. However, the game was marred by the [[2009 Upton Park riot]] which included pitch invasions after both of Stanislas' goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8205836.stm|title=West Ham 3–1 Millwall|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 August 2009 |accessdate=13 October 2009}}</ref> His second goal of the season came on 4 October 2009, when he came off the bench to score a last minute equaliser in a 2–2 draw with [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> His final goal of the season was on 28 November 2009, scoring the second goal in a 5–3 win over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> He remained a first-team player until the end of the season featuring heavily in the run-in as West Ham secured their Premier League safety. Stanislas made a total of 28 appearances in all competitions, scoring 4 goals in the [[2009–10 West Ham United F.C. season|2009–10]] season.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/>
In the summer of 2010, [[Gianfranco Zola]] was replaced by [[Avram Grant]] as manager and Stanislas found himself down the pecking order at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]]. His first appearance of the season was on 24 August 2010, in a 1–0 win over [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] in the League Cup.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> He had a prolonged spell in the first team during November and December, making 5 appearances. On 18 December 2010, he scored the equalising goal against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in a 1–1 draw at [[Ewood Park]], after coming on as a substitute for [[Pablo Barrera]] in the second half.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rs.goal.com/en-us/match/47951/blackburn-vs-west-ham/report# |title=Blackburn vs West Ham Report |publisher=Goal.com |date=18 December 2010 |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref> His final game of the season was on 1 January 2011, in a 2–0 win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. In January 2011, he was ruled out until the end of the season after undergoing hernia surgery.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/> After four months out, he made his comeback for the reserves on 11 May, playing 30 minutes in a 3–2 defeat to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20110511/stanislas-returns-for-reserves_2236884_2358060|title=Stanislas returns for reserves|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|date=11 May 2011|accessdate=2012-06-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827130855/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20110511/stanislas-returns-for-reserves_2236884_2358060|archivedate=27 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made a total of 8 appearances in all competitions, scoring 1 goal in the [[2010–11 West Ham United F.C. season|2010–11]] season as West Ham were relegated to the Championship.<ref name="Player profile Junior Stanislas"/>
The summer again brought a change of manager with [[Sam Allardyce]] replacing the departed Avram Grant. His first game of the season was in the league game against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] on 13 August 2011, coming on as a late substitute for [[Herita Ilunga]] in a 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14429582 |title=Doncaster 0–1 West Ham |publisher=BBC sport |date=13 August 2011 |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref> On 24 August 2011, he scored his first goal of the season in what proved to be his final appearance for the Hammers, in their 2–1 League Cup defeat to [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14569566.stm|title=West Ham 1–2 Aldershot|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 August 2011|accessdate=27 August 2011}}</ref>
===Burnley=== On 31 August 2011, Stanislas joined fellow Championship club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee, becoming the club's seventh summer signing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2437351,00.html |title=Junior jets in! |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=31 August 2011 |accessdate=31 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930013224/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2437351%2C00.html |archivedate=30 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> He stated the main reason for leaving West Ham was due to lack of game time.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/9227369.Stanislas_eager_to_get_started_at_Burnley/|title=Stanislas eager to get started at Burnley|publisher=Lancashire Evening Telegraph|date=1 September 2011|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> His debut for the Clarets came on 10 September, in a 2–0 defeat to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] at [[Turf Moor]], coming on as a second-half substitute for [[Keith Treacy]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/14773085.stm|title=Burnley 0 – 2 Middlesbrough |publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 September 2011|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> His first start for the club came on 24 September, in a 1–1 draw with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14957886|title=Burnley 1 – 1 Southampton |publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 September 2011|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> He provided two assists 3 days later for [[Jay Rodriguez]] in the 5–1 drubbing of [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14982428|title=Burnley 5 – 1 Nott'm Forest |publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 September 2011|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> On 3 December, he returned to his old club as Burnley secured a 2–1 victory, with Stanislas providing the assist for the [[Chris McCann]] equaliser.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15901825|title=West Ham 1 – 2 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 December 2011|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> In January 2012, he sustained a hamstring injury against Middlesbrough which kept him sidelined for two months.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2581416,00.html |title=Paterson and Stanislas Injury Updates |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=30 January 2012 |accessdate=7 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122044918/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2581416%2C00.html |archivedate=22 January 2012 |df= }}</ref> His return came on 10 March 2012, in a 1–1 home draw with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], coming on in the final few minutes for [[Martin Paterson]]. His final appearance of the season was in the 1–1 draw with [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] as Burnley finished mid-table.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17795497|title=Burnley 1–1 Bristol City |publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 April 2012|accessdate=7 June 2012}}</ref> Stanislas made a total of 32 appearances in his debut season for Burnley, scoring no goals. In his second season at Turf Moor, Stanislas was again a regular first-teamer; appearing in all but 11 league matches and scoring 5 goals.
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 26 June 2014, Stanislas joined [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]]. He had been offered a new contract at Turf Moor, but this was turned down in favour of reuniting with former manager [[Eddie Howe]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28037282|title=Junior Stanislas: Bournemouth sign Burnley winger |publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 June 2014|accessdate=28 June 2014}}</ref>
He made his debut for the Cherries on 9 August, coming on in added time for [[Marc Pugh]] as they began [[2014–15 Football League Championship|the season]] with a 4–0 win at [[Huddersfield Town]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Huddersfield 0–4 Bournemouth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28646430|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 August 2014}}</ref> A week later, six minutes after coming off the bench, he finished [[Ryan Fraser]]'s cross for the only goal at [[Dean Court]] against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]];<ref>{{cite news|title=Bournemouth 1–0 Brentford|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28716512|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 August 2014}}</ref> this was his only goal in 13 appearances as Bournemouth won the title, earning their first promotion to the Premier League. On 3 January 2015, in the third round of the FA Cup, Stanislas put Bournemouth in the lead as they came from behind to win 5–1 at [[Rotherham United]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rotherham 1–5 Bournemouth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30608632|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 January 2015}}</ref>
On 25 August 2015, Stanislas scored in each half as Bournemouth defeated [[Hartlepool United]] 4–0 at the [[Victoria Ground]] in the second round of the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hartlepool 0–4 Bournemouth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33969810|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 August 2015}}</ref> His first Premier League goals for the club came on 28 November, two late strikes to seal a 3–3 home draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gheerbrant|first1=James|title=Bournemouth 3–3 Everton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34887539|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 November 2015}}</ref> Two weeks later, Stanislas opened the scoring in the second minute of an eventual 2–1 win over [[Manchester United]], [[Olympic goal|netting directly from a corner kick]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henson|first1=Mike|title=Bournemouth 2–1 Man Utd|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35014111|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 December 2015}}</ref>
==International career== Stanislas has been capped for England at under-19, under-20 and under-21 level.<ref>{{cite news|author=Duncan |url=http://londonist.com/2009/04/football_england_2_italy_0_under_20.php |title=Football: England 2 Italy 0 (Under 20 International Friendly) |publisher=Londonist.com |date=1 April 2009 |accessdate=2010-04-28}}</ref> He was called up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] squad for the first time in November 2007, along with West Ham teammate, [[James Tomkins (footballer)|James Tomkins]], for a friendly against [[Germany national under-19 football team|Germany]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20071114/england-call-stanislas-and-tomkins_2236884_1166558|title=England call Stanislas and Tomkins|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|date=14 November 2007|accessdate=2012-06-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807061528/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20071114/england-call-stanislas-and-tomkins_2236884_1166558|archivedate=7 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His second call-up came in February 2008, for a friendly against [[Croatia national under-19 football team|Croatia]] at the [[County Ground, Swindon]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20080205/stanislas-and-sears-get-england-call_2236884_1231578|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209071318/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20080205/stanislas-and-sears-get-england-call_2236884_1231578|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 February 2013| title=Stanislas and Sears get England call |publisher=West Ham United F.C. |date=5 February 2008 |accessdate=2012-06-07}}</ref> On 31 March 2009, he made his debut for the [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]]'s in a 2–0 win over [[Italy national under-20 football team|Italy]], coming on as a substitute for [[Scott Sinclair]] in a friendly at [[Loftus Road]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stanislas England profile|url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/S/Junior-Stanislas|publisher=[[The Football Association]]}}</ref> He received his first call-up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] side for a friendly against the [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands]] on 11 August 2009 and made his debut starting in the 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=New campaign and new faces for Pearce |url=http://thefa.com/England/MensUnder-21Team/NewsAndFeatures/2009/SquadNamed_HollandGroningen.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715042304/http://thefa.com/England/MensUnder-21Team/NewsAndFeatures/2009/SquadNamed_HollandGroningen.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 July 2012 |publisher=[[The Football Association]] |date=5 August 2009 }}</ref> In September 2009, [[Stuart Pearce]] then named him in the squad for the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification Group 9|2011 European Championship qualifiers]] against [[Macedonia national under-21 football team|Macedonia]] and [[Greece national under-21 football team|Greece]]. His final appearance for the team on 4 September, in the 2–1 victory over Macedonia, before being an unused substitute in the 1–1 draw with Greece four days later.<ref>{{cite news|title=Macedonia Under-21 1 England Under-21 2: match report|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/6139929/Macedonia-Under-21-1-England-Under-21-2-match-report.html|publisher=The Telegraph|date=4 September 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Greece U21 1–1 England U21 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/8245183.stm|publisher=BBS Sport|date=8 September 2009}}</ref>
He is eligible to play for the [[Saint Lucia national football team|Saint Lucia national team]] through his father, Felix. He said "I'm half St Lucian so I could play internationals for them if I wanted... but I don't."<ref>FourFourTwo Magazine. November 2009 edition. p. 34</ref>
==Personal life== Stanislas went to Catholic school as a child and [[Stationers' Crown Woods Academy|Crown Woods School]] in Eltham in his teens.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Premier League Star, Junior Stanislas, Returns To SCWA | publisher = Stationers' Crown Woods Academy | date = 9 February 2018 | accessdate = 6 April 2018 | url = http://scwa.org.uk/2018/02/09/premier-league-star-junior-stanislas-returns-to-scwa/}}</ref> He remains a devout [[Christianity|Christian]] today. His favourite stadium to play at is [[Old Trafford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://xtheline.co.uk/bournemouth-star-reveals-love-jesus/|work=Cross The Line|title=AFC Bournemouth star, Junior Stanislas: "My faith means a lot to me"|author=Ollie Baines|date=3 April 2016|accessdate=28 September 2016}}</ref>

{{Spanish name|Rico|Salguero}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Diego Rico | image = | fullname = Diego Rico Salguero<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127|title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed|publisher=Premier League|date=3 September 2018|accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|2|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Burgos]], Spain | height = 1.81 m | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Left back]] | currentclub = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | clubnumber = 21 | youthyears1 = 2000–2011 | youthclubs1 = [[CD Burgos Promesas 2000|Burgos Promesas]] | youthyears2 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs2 = [[Real Zaragoza|Zaragoza]] | years1 = 2012–2013 | clubs1 = [[Real Zaragoza B|Zaragoza B]] | caps1 = 17 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2013–2016 | clubs2 = [[Real Zaragoza|Zaragoza]] | caps2 = 106 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2016–2018 | clubs3 = [[CD Leganés|Leganés]] | caps3 = 51 | goals3 = 3 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | caps4 = 10 | goals4 = 0 | club-update = 08:05, 22 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Diego Rico Salguero''' (born 23 February 1993) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left back]] for English club [[AFC Bournemouth]].
==Club career== ===Zaragoza=== Born in [[Burgos]], [[Castile and León]], Rico graduated from local [[CD Burgos Promesas 2000]]'s youth system. In June 2011, he joined [[Real Zaragoza]] and was assigned to the ''Juvenil'' squad.<ref>[http://www.burgospromesas.com/secciones/noticias/diego-rico-dejara-el-equipo-de-su-vida-para-fichar-por-el-real-zaragoza Diego Rico dejara el equipo de su vida para fichar por el Real Zaragoza (Diego Rico will leave his lifelong club to sign for Real Zaragoza)]; Burgos Promesas 2000, 4 June 2011 (in Spanish)</ref>
Rico made his senior debut with [[Real Zaragoza B|the reserves]] in [[2011–12 Segunda División B|2011–12]], in [[Segunda División B]], and was quickly promoted to the B-side in July 2012.<ref>[http://www.heraldo.es/noticias/deportes/futbol/real_zaragoza/2012/07/11/el_zaragoza_inicia_este_jueves_pretemporada_195391_611027.html El Zaragoza B inicia este jueves la pretemporada (Zaragoza B start pre-season this Thursday)]; [[Heraldo de Aragón]], 11 July 2012 (in Spanish)</ref> He served mostly as a backup in his two seasons with the squad, [[2012–13 Segunda División B|the second ending in relegation]].
In the summer of 2013, Rico was promoted to the main squad after the injury of [[Abraham Minero]]. On 10 September he played his first match as a professional, starting in a [[2013–14 Copa del Rey|0–1 away loss]] against [[Deportivo Alavés]] for the [[Copa del Rey]].<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2013/09/10/futbol/copa_rey/1378841253.html Borja Viguera noquea al Zaragoza en el añadido (Borja Viguera knocks out Zaragoza in injury time)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 10 September 2013 (in Spanish)</ref> He first appeared in the league four days later, playing the full 90 minutes of a 3–0 home success over [[CD Tenerife]] in the [[Segunda División]] championship.<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2013/09/14/futbol/2adivision/1379182161.html El Zaragoza estrena su casillero de victorias con una goleada (Zaragoza open winning box with a routing)]; Marca, 14 September 2013 (in Spanish)</ref>
On 19 November 2013, Rico renewed his contract with the ''Blanquillos'', signing a five-year deal.<ref>[http://www.realzaragoza.com/noticias/39853 Acuerdo para la renovación del contrato de Diego Rico con el Real Zaragoza (Agreement for Diego Rico's contract renewal with Real Zaragoza]; Real Zaragoza, 19 November 2013 (in Spanish)</ref> In the following month he scored his first professional goal, netting the first of a 2–1 home win against [[Córdoba CF]].<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2013/12/08/futbol/2adivision/1386531606.html El Zaragoza se acerca a los puestos de ascenso (Zaragoza get closer to the promotion places)]; Marca, 8 December 2013 (in Spanish)</ref>
Rico signed his first professional deal on 7 January 2016, becoming a full member of the first team and being assigned the {{abbr|no.|number}} 22 jersey.<ref>[http://www.realzaragoza.com/noticias/54996 Diego Rico firma contrato profesional y a partir de ahora llevará el dorsal 22 (Diego Rico signs professional contract and will wear the 22 jersey from now on)]; Real Zaragoza, 7 January 2016 (in Spanish)</ref> He finished [[2015–16 Segunda División|the campaign]] with one goal<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/20151011/54438038481/1-3-el-zaragoza-vence-al-albacete-en-25-minutos-primorosos.html|title=1–3. El Zaragoza vence al Albacete en 25 minutos primorosos|trans-title=1–3. Zaragoza defeat Albacete in 25 immaculate minutes|publisher=[[La Vanguardia]]|language=es|date=11 October 2015|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref> in 39 matches, contributing to an eighth-place finish.
===Leganés=== On 17 August 2016, Rico signed a four-year contract with [[La Liga]] side [[CD Leganés]]<ref>[http://www.deportivoleganes.com/noticia/diego-rico-juventud-y-potencia-para-el-lateral-izquierdo-pepinero-hasta-2020 Diego Rico, juventud y potencia para el lateral izquierdo pepinero hasta 2020 (David Rico, youth and power to the left ''pepinero'' left flank until 2020)]; CD Leganés, 17 August 2016 (in Spanish)</ref> for a rumoured fee of [[Euro|€]]1 million.<ref>[http://www.marca.com/futbol/leganes/2016/08/17/57b4187046163fc16f8b4590.html Diego Rico llega al Leganés por un millón de euros (Diego Rico arrives at Leganés for one million euros)]; Marca, 17 August 2016 (in Spanish)</ref> He made his debut in the competition five days later, starting and in a 1–0 away win against [[Celta de Vigo]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2016_17/la-liga/jornada_1/cel_leg/|title=Estreno de oro del Leganés en Primera|trans-title=Golden debut of Leganés in ''Primera''|publisher=Marca|first=Borja Luis|last=Callero|language=es|date=22 August 2016|accessdate=22 August 2016}}</ref>
Rico scored his first goal in the [[Spanish football league system|Spanish top flight]] on 11 September 2016, but in a 1–2 loss at [[Sporting de Gijón]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2016_17/la-liga/jornada_3/spo_leg/|title=El Sporting se lleva la victoria ante un Leganés combativo|trans-title=Sporting take win against fighting Leganés|publisher=Marca|first=Íñigo|last=Fernández|language=es|date=11 September 2016|accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref> The following 7 August, he extended his contract until 2021.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deportivoleganes.com/noticia/diego-rico-renovado-hasta-2021|title=Diego Rico, renovado hasta 2021|trans-title=Diego Rico, renewed until 2021|publisher=CD Leganés|language=es|date=7 August 2017|accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 24 July 2018, Rico was transferred to [[AFC Bournemouth]] for an undisclosed fee, and signed a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.afcb.co.uk/news/first-team/cherries-complete-rico-swoop|title=Cherries complete Rico swoop|publisher=AFC Bournemouth|date=24 July 2018|accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> He made his debut in the [[Premier League]] on 1 September, playing the entire 0–2 away defeat against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45305231|title=Chelsea 2–0 AFC Bournemouth|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|first=Neil|last=Johnston|date=1 September 2018|accessdate=3 September 2018}}</ref>
==Career statistics== {{updated|2 March 2019}}<ref>{{soccerway|diego-rico-salguero/238788}}</ref>

Bournemouth]] | clubnumber = 22 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Dallas Texans | youthyears2 = 2010–2011 | youthclubs2 = [[FC Dallas]] | youthyears3 = 2011–2014 | youthclubs3 = [[Fulham F.C. Academy|Fulham]] | years1 = 2014–2016 | clubs1 = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] | caps1 = 25 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2016– | clubs2 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] | caps2 = 1 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017 | clubs3 = → [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] (loan) | caps3 = 13 | goals3 = 4 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] (loan) | caps4 = 15 | goals4 = 1 | pcupdate = 14:48, 1 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalyears1 = 2012 | nationalteam1 = [[United States men's national under-17 soccer team|United States U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam2 = [[United States men's national under-20 soccer team|United States U20]] | nationalcaps2 = 14 | nationalgoals2 = 3 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2016 | nationalteam3 = [[United States men's national under-23 soccer team|United States U23]] | nationalcaps3 = 9 | nationalgoals3 = 1 | nationalyears4 = 2014– | nationalteam4 = [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] | nationalcaps4 = 2 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalteam-update = May 13, 2018 }} '''Emerson Schellas Hyndman''' (born April 9, 1996) is an American [[association football|soccer]] player who plays for [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]], and the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States national team]]. Hyndman, who plays as a [[midfielder]], has also previously played for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] and [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]].
==Club career==
Born in [[Dallas]], Hyndman started his career in the [[U.S. Soccer Development Academy]] with the Dallas Texans before moving on to joining [[FC Dallas]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcdallas.com/post/2011/02/18/fc-dallas-signs-goalkeeper-richard-sanchez|title=FC Dallas signs goalkeeper Richard Sanchez|publisher=FC Dallas Website|date=February 18, 2011|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160621194546/http://www.fcdallas.com/post/2011/02/18/fc-dallas-signs-goalkeeper-richard-sanchez|archivedate=June 21, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref> During his time at FC Dallas, Hyndman attracted interest from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] after the club's director of football [[Dennis Wise]] saw him play, but ultimately Wise opted not to pursue him further.<ref>{{cite news|title=Five-a-side: What's hot around the league|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2010/01/23/five-side-whats-hot-around-league-11|publisher=Major League Soccer Website|date=January 23, 2010|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref>
===Fulham=== Hyndman joined the [[Fulham F.C. Academy|Fulham youth academy]] in 2011 aged 15.<ref>[http://www.yanks-abroad.com/content.php?mode=show&id=10810 "HYNDMAN EMBRACES FULHAM LEGACY"], Yanks Abroad, August 20, 2013. Retrieved August 10, 2014.</ref> Hyndman revealed that the then club's head of youth development, Huw Jennings, convinced him to join the club.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Throw-In: "Fulhamerica" is gone, but does it matter?|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2012/12/20/throw-fulhamerica-gone-does-it-matter|publisher=Major League Soccer Website|date=December 20, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> Hyndman revealed that moving to England was tough initially, but that he soon settled in thanks to the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/march/22/hyndmans-homecoming|title=Hyndman's Homecoming|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=March 22, 2013|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420204010/http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/march/22/hyndmans-homecoming|archivedate=April 20, 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref> In 2012, Hyndman signed his first professional contract with the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/kids-zone/ffc-news/2013/november/05/through-the-ranks-rodak|title=Through The Ranks: Emerson Hyndman|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=November 5, 2013|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912102028/http://www.fulhamfc.com/kids-zone/ffc-news/2013/november/05/through-the-ranks-rodak|archivedate=September 12, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
On August 9, 2014, Hyndman made his professional debut for [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in a [[Football League Championship|Championship]] fixture against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], starting and playing 90 minutes in a 2–1 loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/28646535|title=Match Report|work=BBC.com|date=August 9, 2014}}</ref> In his first season at Fulham, Hyndman made nine league appearances, due to playing in the reserves, being on the substitute bench and being sidelined with a broken collarbone.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sources: Emerson Hyndman sidelined with broken collarbone|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/66/united-states/2015/01/29/8428482/sources-emerson-hyndman-sidelined-with-broken-collarbone|publisher=Goal.com|date=January 29, 2015|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2015/march/19/hyndman-cottage-return|title=Hyndman: Cottage Return|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151028061833/http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2015/march/19/hyndman-cottage-return|archivedate=October 28, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In the 2015–16 season, it was reported by [[Goal.com]] that Hyndman turned down a contract extension twice with the club, leading to attracting interests.<ref>{{cite news|title=American Exports: U-20 standout Emerson Hyndman turns down extension offers with Fulham|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2015/08/05/american-exports-u-20-standout-emerson-hyndman-turns-down-extension-offers-fulham|publisher=MLSsoccer.com|date=August 5, 2015|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> By September, Hyndman would stay at the club.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sources: Emerson Hyndman to stay at Fulham|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/66/united-states/2015/08/31/14927412/sources-emerson-hyndman-to-stay-at-fulham|publisher=Goal.com|date=August 31, 2015|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> Hyndman made his first appearance of 2015–16 season, playing 90 minutes, in a 1–0 loss against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the third round of [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 0-1 Stoke City: Peter Crouch puts Potters through in Capital One Cup|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/fulham-vs-stoke/351310|publisher=Sky Sports|date=September 22, 2015|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> After spending months in the reserves, Hyndman's first league appearance came on December 5, 2015, coming on as a substitute, in a 3–0 loss against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Nottingham Forest 3-0 Fulham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34951381|publisher=BBC Sport|date=December 5, 2015|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> Following this, Hyndman was given a string of regular first team football, though he was left out of the starting eleven on more than one occasion when Fulham faced relegation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham boss on Emerson Hyndman – and why USA international is being kept out of harm's way|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/fulham-boss-emerson-hyndman-usa-11036567|publisher=Get West London|date=March 14, 2016|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> Despite this, Hyndman scored his first professional goal against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on his 20th birthday.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 2–1 Cardiff City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35948814|publisher=BBC Sport|date=April 9, 2016|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> After the match, in which he scored the winning goal, Hyndman was named Man of the Match for his performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2016/april/11/man-of-the-match-result|title=Man Of The Match Result|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=April 11, 2016|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160621211146/http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2016/april/11/man-of-the-match-result|archivedate=June 21, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref>
At the end of the season, manager [[Slaviša Jokanović]] stated Hyndman could leave the club with his blessing<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham manager maintains neither Manchester United target Moussa Dembele nor Emerson Hyndman will leave with his blessing|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/fulham-manager-maintains-neither-manchester-10744706|publisher=Get West London|date=January 17, 2016|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> On May 15, 2016, [[ESPN]] reported that Hyndman would leave Fulham when his contract expires, although it revealed that Fulham would get compensation as a result for Hyndman's departure.<ref>{{cite news|title=Emerson Hyndman to leave Fulham in summer, according to source|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/fulham/story/2873709/emerson-hyndman-to-leave-fulham-in-summer-source|publisher=ESPN|date=June 15, 2016|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== ====2016–17: loan to Rangers==== On June 17, 2016, Hyndman signed a four-year deal with [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] of the [[Premier League]]. He made his first appearance in a League Cup match against [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37103116|title=Morecambe 1-2 Bournemouth |publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 August 2016|accessdate=4 November 2016}}</ref>
On January 9, 2017, Hyndman signed for [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] until the end of the [[2016–17 Scottish Premiership|2016–17 season]].<ref>{{ cite news | url=https://rangers.co.uk/news/headlines/hyndman-joins-gers/ | title=Hyndman Joins The Gers | date=9 January 2017| work=Rangers.co.uk | publisher=Rangers Football Club }}</ref><ref>{{ cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38548416| title=Emerson Hyndman: Rangers complete loan deal for Bournemouth midfielder| publisher=BBC Sport | date=9 January 2017 | first=Richard | last=Wilson }}</ref> Hyndman made his Rangers debut in a [[Scottish Cup]] win over [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] at [[Ibrox Stadium]] on 21 January 2017,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38620153 | title=Rangers 2-1 Motherwell| publisher=BBC Sport | date=21 January 2017 |first=Andy |last=Campbell| accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> and scored his first goal for the club against the same opponents a week later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://spfl.co.uk/premiership/fixture/3638014/|title=Motherwell 0-2 Rangers|publisher=SPFL|date=28 January 2017|accessdate=28 January 2017}}</ref> He was selected as [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] Young Player of the Year for [[2016–17 Rangers F.C. season|2016–17]], despite only joining the club in January.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/football/908342/wes-foderingham-clint-hill-kenny-miller-find-out-who-won-rangers-player-of-the-year/ | title=SIMPLY THE BEST Wes Foderingham, Clint Hill, Kenny Miller? Find out who won Rangers Player of the Year | work=[[The Scottish Sun]] | date=23 April 2017 | accessdate=22 April 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18==== Hyndman returned to Bournemouth after his loan spell with Rangers, but made limited appearances during the 2017–18 season. He appeared in one [[EFL Cup]] tie and two [[FA Cup]] matches, then made his [[Premier League]] debut in May 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/16225285.Premier_League_debut_will_do_Hyndman___39_the_world_of_good__39_/ |title=Premier League debut will do Hyndman 'the world of good' |work=Bournemouth Echo |publisher= |date=14 May 2018 |accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19: loan to Hibernian==== Hyndman was loaned to Scottish Premiership club [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] in August 2018, on a deal due to run until January 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45121851 |title=Emerson Hyndman: Bournemouth midfielder joins Hibernian on loan |work= |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2018 |accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in a 6–0 win against [[Hamilton Academical]] on 6 October 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45688828|title=Hibernian 6-0 Hamilton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 October 2018|accessdate=7 October 2018}}</ref> Hyndman returned to Bournemouth at the end of his loan with Hibernian.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46729230 |title=Emerson Hyndman: Bournemouth midfielder returns from Hibernian at end of loan spell |work= |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2019 |accessdate=1 January 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Hyndman represented the United States at [[United States men's under-17 national soccer team|under-17]] level in 2012.<ref>http://www.ussoccer.com/us-under17-mens-national-team/stats/2012-statistics</ref> He received his first senior call up in August 2014 after making three first team appearances for Fulham.<ref>{{cite news|title=Seattle Sounders academy attacker Jordan Morris, World Cup vet Julian Green highlight USMNT roster vs. Czech Republic|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2014/08/28/seattle-sounders-academy-attacker-jordan-morris-world-cup-vet-julian-green-highlight|publisher=MLS Soccer Website|date=August 28, 2014}}</ref> On August 28, 2014, he was selected to the [[United States men's national soccer team|senior national team]] for their game against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] on September 3.<ref>{{cite news|title=Geoff Cameron ruled out of US national team for friendly in Czech Republic|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2014/08/31/geoff-cameron-ruled-out-us-national-team-friendly-czech-republic|publisher=MLS Website|date=August 31, 2014|accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> He made his senior team debut during the match, being subbed on in the 67th minute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2014/september/04/hyndmans-us-debut|title=Emerson Hyndman's US Debut|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=September 4, 2014|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140909110819/http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2014/september/04/hyndmans-us-debut|archivedate=September 9, 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In May 2015, Hyndman captained the [[United States men's national under-20 soccer team|United States]] side in the [[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in New Zealand. In his first match of the tournament, Hyndman scored the game winner to defeat [[Myanmar national under-20 football team|Myanmar]] 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2015/05/30/01/13/150530-u20mnt-v-mya-gamestory|title=U-20 MNT KICKS OFF 2015 U-20 WORLD CUP WITH 2-1 WIN OVER MYANMAR|work=USSoccer.com}}</ref>
==Personal life== Hyndman is the grandson of former [[FC Dallas]] manager [[Schellas Hyndman]].<ref name="American Exports">{{cite web|title=American Exports: Emerson Hyndman stars in Fulham's win vs. Chelsea in FA Youth Cup final|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/04/28/american-exports-emerson-hyndman-stars-fulhams-1st-leg-win-fa-youth-cup-fina|website=MLS Soccer|publisher=MLS|accessdate=August 9, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429134901/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/04/28/american-exports-emerson-hyndman-stars-fulhams-1st-leg-win-fa-youth-cup-fina|archivedate=April 29, 2014 }}</ref> He holds Portuguese citizenship through his family history.<ref name=Homecoming>{{cite web|title=Emerson Hyndman Has Homecoming at Dallas Cup|url=http://americansoccernow.com/articles/emerson-hyndman-has-homecoming-at-dallas-cup|publisher=American Soccer Now LLC|accessdate=August 9, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809172422/http://americansoccernow.com/articles/emerson-hyndman-has-homecoming-at-dallas-cup|archivedate=August 9, 2014}}</ref>
While growing up in United States, Hyndman excelled in baseball, basketball and soccer, but preferred soccer, as he stated he loved kicking a ball from a young age.<ref>{{cite news|title=Emerson Hyndman|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/kids-zone/academy-access/emerson-hyndman|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=June 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160621202324/http://www.fulhamfc.com/kids-zone/academy-access/emerson-hyndman|archivedate=June 21, 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|14:48, 1 January 2019 (UTC)}}<ref>{{Soccerbase|id=76795}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=January 2019}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Nathaniel Clyne | image = Nathaniel Clyne Southampton FC Manchester United 2012,13.png | image_size = 200 | caption = Clyne with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012 | fullname = Nathaniel Edwin Clyne{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|4|5|df=y}}{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |year=2010 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=87}} | birth_place = [[Stockwell]], England | height = {{height|ft=5|in=9}} | position = [[Right back]] | currentclub = [[AFC Bournemouth]]
(on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = 23 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Afewee Academy{{cite news |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=The Brixton volunteers who made Nathaniel Clyne an England player |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/oct/07/nathaniel-clyne-england-debut-brixton-volunteers |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=27 November 2014 |date=7 October 2014}} | youthyears2 = 1999–2008 | youthclubs2 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | years1 = 2008–2012 | clubs1 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | caps1 = 122 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2012–2015 | clubs2 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] | caps2 = 94 | goals2 = 3 | years3 = 2015– | clubs3 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps3 = 77 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2019– | clubs4 = → [[AFC Bournemouth]] (loan) | caps4 = 9 | goals4 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 9 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2011–2013 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 8 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2014– | nationalteam3 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps3 = 14 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 08:07, 22 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:15, 13 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Nathaniel Edwin Clyne''' (born 5 April 1991) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[right back]] for [[AFC Bournemouth]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from fellow {{English football updater|Liverpoo}} club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. He began his career at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], playing regularly in four [[EFL Championship|Championship]] seasons, before a move to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012, where he spent three seasons in the Premier League. He joined Liverpool in July 2015 for a fee of £12.5 million. Formerly an international at [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 level]], Clyne made his senior international debut for [[England national football team|England]] in November 2014. He was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016]]. ==Club career== ===Crystal Palace=== Clyne was born in [[Stockwell]], London. He made his first-team debut for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in a 3–0 [[EFL Championship|Championship]] win against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] at [[Selhurst Park]] on 18 October 2008.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7665071.stm |title=Crystal Palace 3–0 Barnsley |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 May 2010 |date=18 October 2008}} He signed a three-year professional contract with the club two days later, with manager [[Neil Warnock]] stating that Clyne "has a bright future in the game".{{cite news |url=http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/latestsport/Exclusive-Youngster-pens-year-deal/article-412991-detail/article.html |title=Youngster pens three-year deal |publisher=Croydon advertiser |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024203117/http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/latestsport/Exclusive-Youngster-pens-year-deal/article-412991-detail/article.html |archivedate=24 October 2008}} His first career goal came on 8 December 2009, when he opened a 4–2 win at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in the seventh minute.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8390609.stm "Reading 2–4 Crystal Palace"] BBC Sport. 8 December 2009. Retrieved 4 January 2014. In February 2010 he was offered a move to [[Premier League]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], but rejected it without even entering talks with manager [[Mick McCarthy]].{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_5909424,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Clyne snubs Wolves move |accessdate=19 July 2012 |date=1 February 2010}} In the 2010–11 season, Clyne was the youngest player in the Football League to play every single match of that campaign,{{cite web |title=First Team Profiles: Nathaniel Clyne |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/team/player-profile/nathaniel-clyne/2 |publisher=Southampton F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2014}} and won Crystal Palace's [[Crystal Palace F.C. Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] award.{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/may/cpfc-player-of-the-year---the-history/ |title=CPFC Player of the Year – The history |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2014 |date=6 May 2014}} ===Southampton=== [[File:Nathaniel Clyne (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Clyne playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012]] On 19 July 2012, Clyne signed a four-year deal with newly promoted Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2853579,00.html |publisher=Southampton F.C. |title=Saints Secure Clyne Deal |accessdate=1 July 2015 |date=19 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721232533/http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2853579,00.html |archivedate=21 July 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18890873 |title=Crystal Palace's Nathaniel Clyne seals Southampton move |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 July 2012 |date=19 July 2012}} He made his debut on 19 August, in a 3–2 defeat against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].{{cite news |last=Bevan |first=Chris |title=Man City 3–2 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19231354 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=19 August 2012}} His first match at [[St Mary's Stadium|St Mary's]] came six days later in a 0–2 defeat by [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].{{cite news |last=Monaghan |first=Matt |title=Southampton 0–2 Wigan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19304275 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=25 August 2012}} He scored his first goal for the club on 22 September, in a 4–1 win at home against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], set up by [[Gastón Ramírez]] with [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] coach [[Stuart Pearce]] in attendance at St Mary's.{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Aimee |title=Southampton 4–1 Aston Villa |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19615244 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=22 September 2012}} His second goal for the club came in the [[FA Cup]] third round against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 4 January 2014, opening an eventual 4–3 home victory with a 25-yard strike past [[Tom Heaton]].{{cite news |last=Cryer |first=Andy |title=Southampton 4–3 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25531713 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=4 January 2014}} Clyne scored in Southampton's first match of the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]], a 2–1 defeat against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 17 August.{{cite news |last=Ornstein |first=David |title=Liverpool 2–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730043 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=17 August 2014}} He scored his second goal of the campaign on 23 September, with a long-range effort which gave Southampton a 2–1 victory at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] third round.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29216769 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Arsenal 1–2 Southampton |accessdate=23 September 2014 |date=23 September 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/capital-one-cup/match/406142/arsenal-southampton/report |publisher=ESPN FC |title=Nathaniel Clyne's goal allows Southampton to see off Arsenal |accessdate=23 September 2014 |date=23 September 2014}} On 24 November, he finished [[Ryan Bertrand]]'s 81st-minute cross to earn a 1–1 draw away to Aston Villa.{{cite news |last=Rostance |first=Tom |title=Aston Villa 1–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30077226 |accessdate=24 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2014}} ===Liverpool=== ====2015–2019==== On 1 July 2015, Liverpool confirmed the signing of Clyne from Southampton for £12.5 million on a five-year contract, with his former club, Crystal Palace receiving a payment of £2.5M.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/187852-liverpool-sign-nathaniel-clyne |title=Liverpool sign Nathaniel Clyne |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=1 July 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33344772 |title=Nathaniel Clyne: Liverpool sign defender in £12.5m deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 July 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2015}} Clyne made his debut in a Liverpool shirt against the True Thai Premier League All Stars in [[Bangkok]] on 14 July as part of the club's pre-season tour.{{cite news |url=http://xtra.liverpoolfc.com/news/debuts-goals-and-a-monsoon-liverpool-players-react-on-twitter-to-bangkok-win |title=Debuts, goals and a monsoon – Liverpool players react on twitter to Bangkok win |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919023647/http://xtra.liverpoolfc.com/news/debuts-goals-and-a-monsoon-liverpool-players-react-on-twitter-to-bangkok-win |archivedate=19 September 2015 |deadurl=yes}} He made his competitive debut on 10 August in a 1–0 away win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the first match of the [[2015–16 Premier League]] season.{{cite news |title=Stoke 0–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33750574 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=10 August 2015 |date=9 August 2015}} On 8 October, Clyne scored his first Liverpool goal in a 1–0 [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]] fourth round victory over [[AFC Bournemouth]]; the team's first win under [[Jürgen Klopp]].{{cite news |title=Liverpool 1–0 Bournemouth |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34589602 |accessdate=28 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 October 2015}} His first league goal came on 14 February 2016, in a 6–0 win away to Aston Villa.{{cite news |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Aston Villa 0–6 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35515112 |accessdate=14 February 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 February 2016}} In March 2016, in Liverpool's first European matches against rivals [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], Clyne won a penalty that [[Daniel Sturridge]] converted in the first leg,{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Liverpool 2–0 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35763810 |accessdate=20 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 March 2016}} and conceded a penalty scored by [[Anthony Martial]] in the second, as Liverpool won 3–1 on aggregate in the last 16 of the [[UEFA Europa League]].{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Manchester United 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35815538 |accessdate=20 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 March 2016}} On 18 May, he played the full 90 minutes in the [[2016 UEFA Europa League Final|final]], a 3–1 loss to [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in [[Basel]].{{cite news |title=Sevilla make it three in row at Liverpool's expense |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000663/match=2017222/postmatch/report/index.html |accessdate=1 June 2016 |publisher=UEFA |date=18 May 2016}} Prior to the [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18 season]], Clyne suffered a back injury expected to rule him out until February 2018.{{cite news |last1=Critchley |first1=Mark |title=Liverpool defender Nathaniel Clyne set to miss next three months after operation on back injury |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/nathaniel-clyne-injury-liverpool-fc-news-latest-operation-back-a8052831.html |accessdate=23 January 2018 |work=The Independent |date=13 November 2017}} On 31 March 2018, having missed the entire campaign up to this point, he made his first appearance on the team sheet as an unused substitute in Liverpool's 2–1 league victory away to former club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43524303 |accessdate=31 March 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2018}} A week later on 7 April, he made his long-awaited return, keeping a clean sheet in a 0–0 draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in a [[Merseyside derby]] clash.{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Matt |title=Everton 0–0 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43602490 |accessdate=7 April 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 April 2018}} ====AFC Bournemouth (loan)==== Clyne joined Premier League club Bournemouth on 4 January 2019 on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2018–19 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2018–19 season]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46760201 |title=Nathaniel Clyne: Bournemouth sign Liverpool right-back on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2019 |accessdate=4 January 2019}} He made his debut on 5 January in a 3–1 FA Cup defeat by [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton and Hove Albion]].{{cite web |title=Bournemouth 1 Brighton 3 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46706811 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 January 2019 |date=5 January 2019}} ==International career== Clyne was born in England and is of Grenadian descent.{{cite news |last=Tweedale |first=Alistair |title=One in three players at Euro 2016 could play for another country |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/09/euro-2016-one-in-three-players-could-play-for-another-country/ |accessdate=17 March 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=9 June 2016}} On 2 October 2014, Clyne was named in the [[England national football team|England]] squad for the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|UEFA Euro 2016 qualifiers]] against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] later that month.{{cite news |title=England squad: Nathaniel Clyne and Jonjo Shelvey called up |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29460356 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 October 2014 |date=2 October 2014}} He was an unused substitute in both matches. Clyne said "My aim, now, is to try to make myself first choice for Euro 2016. That's what I'm going to keep pushing for."{{cite news |title=Nathaniel Clyne wants to make himself first choice right-back for England at Euro 2016 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/southamptons-nathaniel-clyne-wants-make-4610333 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=27 October 2015 |date=11 November 2014}} On 15 November, he made his full international debut in a home qualifier against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]], playing the full 90 minutes of a 3–1 victory.{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=England 3–1 Slovenia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29964707 |accessdate=15 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 November 2014}} Clyne went on to establish himself as first choice right back for England, appearing in five of their last six qualifiers.{{cite news |title=Euro 2016: Who will make England's starting XI in France? |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34506013 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=27 October 2015 |date=13 October 2015}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 16 March 2019}} {| League]] runner-up: [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|2015–16]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36254631 |title=Liverpool 1–3 Sevilla |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 May 2016 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} *[[UEFA Champions League]] runner-up: [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League|2017–18]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44258022 |title=Real Madrid 3–1 Liverpool |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} '''Individual''' *[[PFA Team of the Year]]: [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 3|2011–12 Championship]]{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17797832 |title=Arsenal striker Robin van Persie named PFA Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=23 May 2018}} *[[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] Young Player of the Year: [[2008–09 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2008–09]], [[2009–10 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2009–10]] *[[Football League Awards|Football League]] Young Player of the Year: [[Football League Awards#2010 Awards|2010]] *[[UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] Technical Selection: [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Technical team selection|2010]] *[[Crystal Palace F.C. Player of the Year|Crystal Palace Player of the Year]]: [[2010–11 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2010–11]] *[[EFL Championship Player of the Month|Football League Championship Player of the Month]]: [[2011–12 Football League Championship#Monthly awards|October 2011]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[https://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/nathaniel-clyne Profile] at the Liverpool F.C. website *{{Soccerbase}} {{Navboxes | title = Awards | bg = gold | fg = navy | list1 = {{2011–12 Football League Championship PFA Team of the Year}} {{The Football League Young Player of the Year}} {{Crystal Palace F.C.
