{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Chris Mepham | fullname = Christopher James Mepham<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-professional-retain-list--free-transfers---2017-18.pdf |title=Club list of registered players: As at 19th May 2018: Brentford |publisher=English Football League |format=PDF |page=8 |accessdate=16 June 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|11|5|df=y}}<ref name="AFCBprofile" /> | birth_place = [[Greenford]], England<ref name="AFCBprofile">{{Cite web |url=https://www.afcb.co.uk/teams/first-team/chris-mepham |title=Chris Mepham |website=AFCB |accessdate=31 January 2019}}</ref> | height = {{convert|1.91|m|order=flip}}<ref name="AFCBprofile" /> | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre-back]] | currentclub = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] | clubnumber = 33 | youthyears1 = 2008–2012 | youthclubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | youthyears2 = 2012–2016 | youthclubs2 = [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] | years1 = 2016–2019 | clubs1 = [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] | caps1 = 43 | goals1 = 1 | clubs2 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] | years2 = 2019– | caps2 = 7 | goals2 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2017 | nationalteam1 = [[Wales national under-20 football team|Wales U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2017– | nationalteam2 = [[Wales national under-21 football team|Wales U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 4 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2018– | nationalteam3 = [[Wales national football team|Wales]] | nationalcaps3 = 5 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 08:12, 22 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 24 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Christopher James Mepham''' (born 5 November 1997) is a professional [[association football|football]] [[central defender]] who plays for [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. He is a product of the [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] [[Football academy|academies]] and is a [[Wales national football team|Wales]] international.
== Club career ==
=== Early years === A [[Defender (association football)|centre back]] and occasional right back,<ref name="contracts">{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2016/february/youth-team-duo-sign-first-professional-contracts-/ |title=Brentford FC Youth Team duo sign first professional contracts |accessdate=25 August 2017 |language=en-gb}}</ref> Mepham began his career in the [[Chelsea F.C. Academy|academy]] at [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at the age of 10.<ref name="MND">{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/june/youth-team-player-backs-football-v-mnd/ |title=Brentford FC |accessdate=25 August 2017 |language=en-gb}}</ref> He was released at the age of 14 and was then turned down by [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] and [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref name="James">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/mar/21/chris-mepham-ryan-giggs-brentford-premier-league-wales |title=Chris Mepham: ‘It’s surreal that Ryan Giggs wants to have a chat with you’ |last=James |first=Stuart |date=21 March 2018 |website=the Guardian |language=en |access-date=22 March 2018}}</ref>
=== Brentford ===
==== Youth years (2012–2016) ==== Mepham joined the [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy|academy]] at [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in 2012,<ref name="MND" /> after being spotted by the club's Head of Academy Recruitment while making a one-off appearance for [[North Greenford United F.C.|North Greenford United]]'s reserve team.<ref name="James" /> After making three appearances for the [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy|youth team]] as an U16,<ref name="YT1314">{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/april/201314-youth-team-statistics/ |title=Brentford FC |accessdate=25 August 2017 |language=en-gb}}</ref> Mepham signed a scholarship deal in June 2014.<ref name="MND" /> On 2 February 2016 it was announced that Mepham had signed his first professional contract to be a member of the club's [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy|development squad]] and he finished his scholarship having made 43 appearances and scored two goals for the youth team.<ref name="contracts" /><ref name="YT1314" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2015/may/201415-youth-team-player-statistics/|title=Brentford FC|last=|first=|date=|work=|accessdate=25 August 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|language=en-gb}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/stats/youth-team-player-stats.aspx|title=Youth Team Player Stats|last=|first=|date=|website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160907050836/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/stats/youth-team-player-stats.aspx|archivedate=7 September 2016|dead-url=yes|accessdate=6 January 2017}}</ref> After consistently good performances for the reformed [[Brentford F.C. Reserves and Academy#Relaunch (2016–present)|B team]] during the first half of the [[2016–17 Brentford F.C. season|2016–17]] season, Mepham signed a two-year contract extension on 6 January 2017 and the following day,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/january/chris-mepham-signs-contract-extension/|title=Brentford FC Chris Mepham signs contract extension|last=|first=|date=|work=|accessdate=25 August 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|language=en-gb}}</ref> he made his senior debut as a late substitute for [[Harlee Dean]] during a 5–1 [[FA Cup]] third round victory over [[Eastleigh F.C.|Eastleigh]].<ref name="Soccerbase1617" /> A successful 2016–17 season saw Mepham named as the club's B Team Player of the Year.<ref name="POTY">{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/may2/201617-awards-winners/ |title=Brentford FC 2016/17 Awards Winners |accessdate=26 May 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
==== Breakthrough (2016–2019) ==== After the departure of centre back Harlee Dean on 30 August 2017,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-hand-first-team-promotion-13587908|title=Brentford hand first team promotion to young defender|last=Moore|first=Tom|date=7 September 2017|work=getwestlondon|accessdate=7 September 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=}}</ref> Mepham was promoted into the first team squad and signed a new five-year contract.<ref name="brentfordfc">{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/september/chris-mepham/|title=Brentford FC Chris Mepham signs new long-term contract|accessdate=18 September 2017|language=en-gb}}</ref> He made his first start for the club in a 3–1 [[EFL Cup]] third round defeat to [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on 19 September 2017 and gave away the [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] which led to the Canaries' opening goal.<ref name="Soccerbase1718" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/fixtures/first-team/201718/september/brentford-vs-norwich-city-on-19-sep-17/#report|title=Brentford vs Norwich City on 19 Sep 17 – Match Centre – Brentford FC|last=|first=|date=|website=www.brentfordfc.com|language=en-gb|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=19 September 2017}}</ref> After appearing sporadically throughout the autumn,<ref name="Soccerbase1718" /> a head injury suffered by [[John Egan (footballer, born 1992)|John Egan]] in December allowed Mepham a run in the team from the [[Christmas]] period until early February 2018.<ref name="Soccerbase1718" /><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/dean-smith-outlines-hopes-plans-14098357 |title=Dean Smith outlines hopes and plans for Brentford's youngsters |last=Moore |first=Tom |date=2 January 2018 |work=getwestlondon |accessdate=2 January 2018}}</ref> An achilles injury suffered by [[Andreas Bjelland]] in mid-March allowed Mepham back into the team and he scored the first senior goal of his career with the equaliser in a 1–1 draw with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on [[Good Friday]].<ref name="Soccerbase1718" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-boss-explains-andreas-bjelland-14394783|title=Brentford boss on Bjelland injury and Millwall loss|last=Moore|first=Tom|date=10 March 2018|work=getwestlondon|access-date=1 April 2018}}</ref> He finished the [[2017–18 Brentford F.C. season|2017–18]] season with 23 appearances and one goal.<ref name="Soccerbase1718" />
Mepham began the [[2018–19 Brentford F.C. season|2018–19]] season as the Bees' undisputed first choice centre back in league matches, but was [[Red card (association football)|sent off]] for the first time in his career for two [[Yellow card (association football)|bookable offences]] committed during a 1–0 defeat to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 20 October 2018.<ref name="Soccerbase1819" /> He made 27 appearances before departing the club for a club-record transfer fee in January 2019.<ref name="Soccerbase1819" /><ref name="LeavesBrentford">{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2019/january/chris-mepham-departs-22.01.19/ |title=Chris Mepham leaves Brentford to join AFC Bournemouth |website=www.brentfordfc.com |language=en-gb |accessdate=31 January 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fmHPAO0lnKM |title=Phil Giles' January Round Up |date=31 January 2019 |publisher=brentfordfc.com |time=0:59 |accessdate=31 January 2019 |medium=Interview}}</ref> During his two-and-a-half seasons as a professional at [[Griffin Park]], Mepham made 48 appearances and scored one goal.<ref>{{Soccerbase|id=100492}}</ref>
=== Bournemouth === On 22 January 2019, Mepham signed a "long-term" contract with [[Premier League]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for an undisclosed fee,<ref name="LeavesBrentford" /> reported to be £12 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11743/11614317/chris-mepham-joins-bournemouth-from-brentford-for-12m|title=Chris Mepham joins Bournemouth from Brentford for £12m|website=Sky Sports|language=en|access-date=31 January 2019}}</ref> Eight days later, he made his debut for the club as a substitute for [[Junior Stanislas]] late in a 4–0 win over Chelsea.<ref name="Soccerbase1819" /> He continued to be regularly selected within the back line at Bournemouth due to the absence of [[Steve Cook]] through injury.
== International career == He was called into the [[Wales national under-20 football team|Wales U20]] squad for the [[2017 Toulon Tournament]] and made one appearance,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/may2/chris-mepham-wales/|title=Brentford FC Chris Mepham heading to Toulon Tournament|last=|first=|date=|work=|accessdate=27 May 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> in a 2–2 group stage draw with [[Ivory Coast national under-20 football team|Ivory Coast]] on 5 June 2017.<ref>{{Soccerway|id=471436|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref> He made his [[Wales national under-21 football team|U21]] debut with a start in a 3–0 [[2019 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 8|2019 UEFA U21 Championship qualifying]] victory over [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|Switzerland]] on 2 September 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/september/international-round-up-b-team/|title=Brentford FC Mepham and Balcombe help home nations to wins|last=|first=|date=|work=|accessdate=3 September 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|language=en-gb}}</ref> Mepham [[Captain (association football)|captained]] the U21 team for the first time in a 0–0 qualifying draw with [[Romania national under-21 football team|Romania]] six weeks later.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/november/youth-international-round-up-20171115/|title=Brentford FC Mepham and Mads captain nations in Euro Qualifiers|accessdate=15 November 2017|language=en-gb}}</ref>
In March 2018, Mepham won his maiden call-up to the [[Wales national football team|senior team]] for the [[2018 China Cup]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2018/march/chris-mepham-wales/|title=Brentford FC Chris Mepham gets maiden full Wales Call-up|access-date=15 March 2018|language=en-gb}}</ref> He made his debut as a substitute for [[Ben Davies (footballer, born 1993)|Ben Davies]] after 70 minutes of a 6–0 victory over [[China national football team|China]] on 22 March 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2018/march/international-round-up-23-march/|title=Brentford FC Wins for Mepham and Dalsgaard on international stage|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=23 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-gb}}</ref> Two months later, he made his first international start, in a 0–0 [[Friendly match|friendly]] draw with [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] on 28 May.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2018/may/international-review-20180529/|title=Chris Mepham impresses on full debut for Wales|access-date=29 May 2018|language=en-gb}}</ref>
== Personal life == Mepham attended [[Queensmead School]] in [[South Ruislip]] and is a [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] supporter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://doczz.net/doc/4077071/newsletter---queensmead-school|title=newsletter – Queensmead School – football|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/september/brentford-gave-everything-in-west-london-derby/|title=Brentford FC BRENTFORD 'GAVE EVERYTHING' IN WEST LONDON DERBY|last=|first=|date=|work=|accessdate=8 September 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|language=en-gb}}</ref> His uncle Roy was a member of the Brentford youth team in the 1960s.<ref name="MND" />

{{About|the footballer|the professional wrestler|Mark Briscoe}} {{Use British English|date=December 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Good article}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Marc Pugh | image = Marc Pugh 17-03-2015 1.jpg | image_size = 150 | caption = Pugh playing for [[AFC Bournemouth]] in 2015 | fullname = Marc Anthony Pugh{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|4|2|df=y}}{{Hugman|25021|accessdate=10 February 2018}} | birth_place = [[Bacup]], England | height = {{convert|1.80|m|order=flip}}{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/marc-pugh/50754/ |title=M. Pugh: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=31 October 2018}} | position = [[Midfielder]] / [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]
(on loan from [[AFC Bournemouth]]) | clubnumber = 8 | youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2004 | youthclubs1 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | years1 = 2004–2006 | clubs1 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2005 | clubs2 = → [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]] (loan) | caps2 = 5 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2006 | clubs3 = → [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]] (loan) | caps3 = 2 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2006–2007 | clubs4 = [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] | caps4 = 41 | goals4 = 4 | years5 = 2007–2009 | clubs5 = [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] | caps5 = 44 | goals5 = 4 | years6 = 2008 | clubs6 = → [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] (loan) | caps6 = 4 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2009 | clubs7 = → [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] (loan) | caps7 = 9 | goals7 = 1 | years8 = 2009–2010 | clubs8 = [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] | caps8 = 40 | goals8 = 13 | years9 = 2010– | clubs9 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | caps9 = 274 | goals9 = 45 | years10 = 2019– | clubs10 = → [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] (loan) | caps10 = 9 | goals10 = 2 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | club-update = 19:32, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Marc Anthony Pugh''' (born 2 April 1987) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] of the {{English football updater|HullCity}}, on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|AFCBourn}} club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. He plays mainly as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] but can also play as a [[midfielder]]. Pugh started his career with [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], where he progressed through the youth system. He was released by the club having made his first team while on loan at [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]] and signed a short-term contract with [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] in 2006. Pugh later signed a professional contract at the club and after rejecting an extended contract in 2007 he signed for [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]]. He was loaned out to [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] and [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]], joining the latter permanently in 2009. Pugh left Hereford after one season to sign for Bournemouth in 2010, where he was top scorer in his first two seasons. He has since made over 300 appearances for the club, helping them win [[Promotion and relegation|promotion]] to the Championship in 2013 and the Premier League two years later. As a result, Pugh has played and scored in all five of England's nationwide football divisions. ==Early and personal life== Pugh was born in [[Bacup]], Lancashire{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |year=2010 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=341}} to Tony and Denise. He grew up in [[Stacksteads]] and attended [[All Saints' Catholic High School, Rawtenstall]].{{cite news |title=Making a Marc – footballer Marc Pugh's Free Press diary |url=https://www.rossendalefreepress.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/making-marc---footballer-marc-1706547 |newspaper=Rossendale Free Express |date=1 October 2010 |accessdate=30 May 2018}} He is married to Laura, with whom he has two daughters. Pugh is a devout Christian.{{cite news |first=Lauren |last=Howard |title=Marc Pugh: I've got a great life and I owe it all to God |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/14242715.Marc_Pugh__I___ve_got_a_great_life_and_I_owe_it_all_to_God/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=31 January 2016 |accessdate=30 September 2016}} ==Career== ===Burnley=== Pugh started his career with [[Football League First Division|First Division]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] where, at a young age, he started as a Centre of Excellence player, and gradually worked his way up through the ranks to become an apprentice in 2003.{{cite news |title=Marc Pugh goes out to Kidderminster |website=TheFootballNetwork.net |publisher=DA Group |url=http://www.thefootballnetwork.net/main/s37/st85191.htm |date=10 November 2005 |accessdate=2 July 2017}} As a first year apprentice he played for the youth and reserve teams and due to his great goalscoring record, which led to him being named on the bench for two first-team matches in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]], they decided to keep him on for a third year. As a third year apprentice he scored 15 goals for the club's reserve and youth team.{{cite news |first=Tony |last=Scholes |title=Pugh gets deal |url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/pugh_gets_deal_282980/index.shtml |website=Clarets Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=16 May 2006 |accessdate=19 May 2011}} This led to him to being [[Loan (sports)|loaned]] out to [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]] of the [[Conference National]] in November 2005 to play first team football.{{cite news |title=Kidderminster agree deal for Pugh |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/k/kidderminster_harriers/4424424.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 November 2005 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He made his debut for Kidderminster after coming on as an 86th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 3–1 defeat to [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage Borough]]. He converted a [[Simon Heslop]] [[Cross (football)|cross]] during a match against [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] to score his first career goal, which helped Kidderminster to a 3–1 victory.{{cite news |title=Kidderminster 3–1 Dag & Red |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/4472998.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 December 2005 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Also, during a match he displayed a smart piece of skill which involved flicking the ball over an opponents head with his heel, then crossing the ball in for a teammate to score; this move was featured on ''[[Soccer AM]]'''s [[Showboat#Showboating|showboating]] section.{{cite web |title=Marc Pugh |url=http://www.shrewsburytown.com/page/QandA/0,,10443~1146115,00.html |publisher=Shrewsbury Town F.C. |date=18 October 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705214147/http://www.shrewsburytown.com/page/QandA/0%2C%2C10443~1146115%2C00.html |archivedate=5 July 2008 |deadurl=yes}} He returned to Burnley on 13 December 2005 after picking up a groin injury,{{cite news |title=Pugh returns from Harriers spell |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/4523850.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2005 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} but returned to Kidderminster for a second loan spell on 7 January 2006.{{cite web |title=Pugh resumes harriers spell |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~765006,00.html |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=7 January 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719151929/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~765006%2C00.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |deadurl=yes}} This spell ended on 26 January 2006 so Pugh could concentrate on his career at Burnley,{{cite news |title=Pugh returns from Harriers spell |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/4650330.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 January 2006 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} having made 10 appearances and scored 1 goal while at Kidderminster. He learned that he would not receive a professional contract at Burnley in February 2006, which was partly because both [[Chris McCann]] and [[Kyle Lafferty]] had both already received professional contracts and they were only second year apprentices.{{cite web |title=Youth team news |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~795034,00.html |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=27 February 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719151944/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~795034%2C00.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |deadurl=yes}} ===Bury=== Having just been released from Burnley, Pugh signed for [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] on a short-term contract on 23 March 2006, following a three-week [[Trial (association football)|trial]].{{cite news |title=Shakers capture midfield quartet |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bury/4836832.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 March 2006 |accessdate=16 December 2015}}{{cite news |title=Shakers sign Pugh |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/715043.Shakers_sign_Pugh/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=24 March 2006 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Bury were entangled in a [[Promotion and relegation|relegation]] battle, and Pugh made his debut two days later after coming on as an 80th-minute substitute in a 2–1 home win over [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]].{{cite news |title=Bury 2–1 Rochdale |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/4819762.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 March 2006 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He marked his first start for Bury with a goal from 10 yards in a 1–1 away draw with [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] on 15 April 2006,{{cite news |title=Lincoln City 1–1 Bury |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/4890980.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 April 2006 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} after which [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Chris Casper]] commented "Mark's a good player and he's got a bright future if he keeps his feet on the ground".{{cite news |title=Casper pays tribute to Pugh |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/casper-pays-tribute-to-pugh-1027072 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=17 April 2006 |accessdate=30 May 2018}} He finished the 2005–06 season by playing six matches and scoring one goal for the club. As a result of his good performances, and helped by the fact that Bury had survived relegation in 19th place, Bury manager Chris Casper offered him a new one-year contract at [[Gigg Lane]]; his first professional contract.{{cite web |title=Three extend at Gigg |url=http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10422~832460,00.html |publisher=Bury F.C. |date=23 May 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004034112/http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10422~832460%2C00.html |archivedate=4 October 2011 |deadurl=yes}}{{cite web |title=League Two: 2005/06: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=242 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} Pugh was a regular first-team player in 2006–07, playing particularly well in the first half of the season, and was offered an extended contract at the club in January 2007.{{cite web |title=Contracts on cards for Shakers duo |url=http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10422~966896,00.html |publisher=Bury F.C. |date=18 January 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213160007/http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10422~966896%2C00.html |archivedate=13 February 2012 |deadurl=yes}} Pugh rejected this in February 2007, saying he "wanted to keep his options open".{{cite news |title=Pugh rejects new Bury contract |publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bury/6362161.stm |date=14 February 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2015}} Casper revealed his disappointment at this and Pugh later said financial reasons were his motivation to reject a new contract.{{cite web |title=Casper 'let down' by contract rebel Pugh |url=http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10422~982967,00.html |publisher=Bury F.C. |date=16 February 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004034214/http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10422~982967%2C00.html |archivedate=4 October 2011 |deadurl=yes}}{{cite web |title=Money not reason for deal delay – Pugh |url=http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10422~983880,00.html |publisher=Bury F.C. |date=19 February 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004034230/http://www.buryfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10422~983880%2C00.html |archivedate=4 October 2011 |deadurl=yes}} He was offered renewed contracts throughout the season but still took none of them, which Casper blamed on his agent.{{cite news |first=Tony |last=Scholes |title=Pugh signs for Shrews |url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/pugh_signs_for_shrews_339771/index.shtml |website=Clarets Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=29 May 2007 |accessdate=2 July 2017}} Pugh finished 2006–07 with 41 appearances and 4 goals for Bury; they finished in 21st place in League Two.{{cite web |title=League Two: 2006/07: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=241 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} ===Shrewsbury Town=== With many clubs interested in his services, Pugh signed for fellow League Two club [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] on 29 May 2007 for a compensation fee.{{cite news |title=Shrews complete signing of trio |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/shrewsbury/6703637.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2007 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Shrewsbury manager [[Gary Peters (footballer)|Gary Peters]] revealed that he had already attempted to sign him earlier in the season as part of a swap deal when striker [[Glynn Hurst]] moved to Bury. He made his debut in a 4–0 away win over Lincoln City, setting up [[Andy Cooke]] for the third goal with a cross.{{cite news |title=Lincoln 0–4 Shrewsbury |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/6931021.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2007 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He suffered an injury in November 2007 and underwent a scan, which was believed to be a cartilage problem.{{cite web |title=Tudor and Pugh |url=http://www.shrewsburytown.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10443~1177136,00.html |publisher=Shrewsbury Town F.C. |date=27 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716064649/http://www.shrewsburytown.com/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10443~1177136%2C00.html |archivedate=16 July 2011 |deadurl=yes}} Days after discovering the results of the scan, which revealed he was suffering from acute tendinitis, he returned to training.{{cite news |title=Pugh returns to Shrews' training |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/shrewsbury/7138692.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 December 2007 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He scored his first goal for Shrewsbury on his return in a 4–0 home victory over Dagenham & Redbridge, turning in a [[Marc Tierney]] cross in the 78th minute before [[Assist (football)|assisting]] Tierney for Shrewsbury's final goal.{{cite news |title=Shrewsbury 4–0 Dag & Red |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/7134235.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 December 2007 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He scored a further two goals that season following the arrival of [[Paul Simpson (footballer)|Paul Simpson]] as manager, and finished 2007–08 with 38 appearances and 4 goals, for a Shrewsbury team that ranked 18th place in League Two.{{cite web |title=League Two: 2007/08: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=240 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} After struggling to feature in the team at the start of 2008–09,{{cite web |title=Player out on loan |url=http://www.shrewsburytown.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10443~1389655,00.html |publisher=Shrewsbury Town F.C. |date=12 September 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716064532/http://www.shrewsburytown.com/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10443~1389655%2C00.html |archivedate=16 July 2011 |deadurl=yes}} Pugh joined fellow League Two club [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] on a one-month loan on 12 September 2008.{{cite news |title=Luton sign Shrews winger on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/luton_town/7611766.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 September 2008 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} His debut came in a 3–1 home win over [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] a day later, after which manager [[Mick Harford]] said "He is an out and out winger, and he put in some good crosses. But he hasn't played a lot of football this season and he maybe faded a bit".{{cite news |title=Brill warned to fight for place |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/luton_town/7616711.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 September 2008 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He returned to Shrewsbury after playing in four matches for Luton. He was loaned out to [[EFL League One|League One]] team [[Hereford United F.C.|Hereford United]] on 26 March 2009,{{cite news |title=Hereford make two loan signings |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hereford_united/7965761.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 March 2009 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} and made his debut two days later in a 1–0 home loss to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]]. Pugh scored his first goal for Hereford with an equaliser against [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] on 4 April 2009, to make the score 2–2, although Hereford eventually lost 4–2. He finished the loan spell with nine appearances and one goal, as Hereford were relegated after finishing bottom of League Two.{{cite web |title=League Two: 2008/09: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=227 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} He was released by Shrewsbury after having the remaining year of his contract cancelled on 26 June 2009.{{cite news |title=Shrewsbury sign Falkirk's Holden |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/shrewsbury/8121335.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 June 2009 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} ===Hereford United=== Pugh re-joined Hereford on a permanent basis following their relegation into League Two, signing a one-year contract on 30 June 2009.{{cite news |title=Bulls sign Pugh and Constantine |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hereford_united/8125740.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Upon this move, he realised that he "needed to knuckle down and get on the football ladder now, because this could be my last opportunity".{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Ames |title=Bournemouth wide man Marc Pugh takes roundabout route to the top |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/04/bournemouth-marc-pugh-premier-league |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=4 August 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He scored twice on his second debut for Hereford, the first from a long-range shot in the 39th minute and the second a 90th-minute equaliser, as they drew 2–2 away to [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]] on 8 August 2009.{{cite news |title=Morecambe 2–2 Hereford |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/8186320.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2009 |accessdate=26 December 2015}} Pugh finished [[2009–10 Hereford United F.C. season|2009–10]] as Hereford's top scorer with 13 goals in 46 appearances.{{cite web |title=Hereford: Squad stats: 2009/10 |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?season_id=144&team_id=1216&teamTabs=stats&season_id=139 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} His goals were credited with helping stabilise Hereford, as they finished in 16th place in League Two.{{cite web |title=League Two: 2009/10: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=7 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} He left Hereford at the end of the season after rejecting a new two-year contract.{{cite news |title=Hereford United braced for Marc Pugh departure |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hereford_united/8691656.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2015}}{{cite news |title=Marc Pugh rejects fresh contract with Hereford United |url=https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/2010/05/20/marc-pugh-rejects-fresh-contract-with-hereford-united/ |newspaper=Shropshire Star |location=Telford |date=20 May 2010 |accessdate=24 June 2017}} ===AFC Bournemouth=== ====2010–2013==== Pugh signed for newly promoted League One club [[AFC Bournemouth]] on 4 June 2010 on a three-year contract, for a compensation fee.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Updated: Cherries swoop for Lovell, Symes and Pugh |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8202203.Updated__Cherries_swoop_for_Lovell__Symes_and_Pugh/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=21 December 2015}}{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Pugh compensation decided |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8339011.Cherries__Pugh_compensation_decided/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=18 August 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} The fee of £100,000, which was decided by a tribunal, was described as "quite excessive" by Bournemouth vice-chairman Jeff Mostyn.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Mostyn's shocked by Pugh tribunal fee |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8339586.Cherries__Mostyn_s_shocked_by_Pugh_tribunal_fee/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=19 August 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Pugh made his debut on 7 August 2010 in a 1–0 away defeat to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], and his first goal of [[2010–11 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2010–11]] came after heading in a [[Liam Feeney]] cross in a 5–1 home win over [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] on 14 August.{{cite news |title=Bournemouth 5–1 Peterborough |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8897709.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He was praised for a "virtuoso performance" by the ''[[Bournemouth Daily Echo]]''.{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries' Pugh: Let me entertain you |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8335118.Cherries__Pugh__Let_me_entertain_you/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=17 August 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Pugh had a strong start to his Bournemouth career, and was leading the club's goalscoring charts with six goals by mid-October 2010.{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Pugh spurred on by scoring spree |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8461929.Cherries__Pugh_spurred_on_by_scoring_spree/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=20 October 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Bournemouth qualified for the [[EFL League One play-offs|League One play-offs]] with a sixth-place finish,{{cite web |title=League One: 2010/11: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=6 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} and Pugh played in both legs of their semi-final with Huddersfield. They were eliminated after a 4–2 defeat on [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]], having drawn 4–4 on aggregate over the two legs. Pugh was Bournemouth's top scorer in 2010–11, with 13 goals from 47 appearances.{{cite web |title=Bournemouth: Squad stats: 2010/11 |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=359&teamTabs=stats&season_id=140 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} Pugh was one of Bournemouth's most consistent players as they made an indifferent start to [[2011–12 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2011–12]], having scored 4 goals from 11 appearances by mid-September 2011.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: In-form Marc targets home improvement |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9259756.Cherries__In_form_Marc_targets_home_improvement/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=20 September 2011 |accessdate=22 December 2015}} Bournemouth opened contract talks with him in December 2011,{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Club is in talks with star Pugh |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9410275.Cherries__Club_is_in_talks_with_star_Pugh/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=22 December 2015}} and he opted to bide his time over the offer of a new three-and-a-half-year deal to concentrate on his playing performances.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Pugh's focus on push for play-offs |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9469371.Cherries__Pugh_s_focus_on_push_for_play_offs/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=13 January 2012 |accessdate=22 December 2015}} Pugh finished 2011–12 as Bournemouth's top scorer for the second season running, with 12 goals from 49 appearances,{{cite web |title=Bournemouth: Squad stats: 2011/12 |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=359&teamTabs=stats&season_id=141 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} while they finished in 11th place in League One.{{cite web |title=League One: 2011/12: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=941 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} He was voted the ''Bournemouth Daily Echo'' Supporters' Player of the Year; this newspaper described him as "a rare shining light during an up-and-down campaign".{{cite news |title=Cherries: Award-winner Pugh set for summer contract talks |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9690055.Cherries__Award_winner_Pugh_set_for_summer_contract_talks/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=5 May 2012 |accessdate=22 December 2015}} He decided not to sign a new contract with Bournemouth in July 2012, and the club was willing to listen to offers for him.{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Pugh's Dean Court future is in doubt |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9785870.Cherries__Pugh_s_Dean_Court_future_is_in_doubt/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=28 June 2012 |accessdate=22 December 2015}} Pugh remained with Bournemouth for [[2012–13 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2012–13]], with the club not receiving any offers for him over the summer of 2012.{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Groves refuses to rule out late deadline-day drama |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/9905238.Cherries__Groves_refuses_to_rule_out_late_deadline_day_drama/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=31 August 2012 |accessdate=23 December 2015}} He started the season in indifferent form, much like the rest of the team, and had a brief spell on the bench during September 2012.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Pugh says players have to feed fans' expectations |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9941647.Cherries__Pugh_says_players_have_to_feed_fans__expectations/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=21 September 2012 |accessdate=23 December 2015}} He described [[Eddie Howe]] as a manager who "expects and demands the best" upon his re-appointment at Bournemouth; Pugh scored in the returning manager's first match in charge, a 2–0 home win over [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 13 October 2012.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Pugh warns squad of ruthless Howe |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9984330.Cherries__Pugh_warns_squad_of_ruthless_Howe/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=15 October 2012 |accessdate=23 December 2015}} Pugh signed a new three-and-a-half-year contract with the club in November 2012, tying him to the club until the summer of 2016.{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Pugh highlights Howe factor after signing deal |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/10061271.Cherries__Pugh_highlights_Howe_factor_after_signing_deal/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=21 November 2012 |accessdate=23 December 2015}} He cited the return of Howe and Bournemouth's promotion credentials as his reasons for signing a new contract. He established himself as an important player for Bournemouth in 2012–13, as they pushed for promotion.{{cite news |title=Cherries: Pugh could return at Deepdale |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/10230169.Cherries__Pugh_could_return_at_Deepdale/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=14 February 2013 |accessdate=23 December 2015}} They finished the season with promotion into the [[EFL Championship|Championship]] as League One runners-up,{{cite web |title=League One: 2012/13: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=1161 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} Pugh having contributed with 8 goals from 46 appearances. ====2013–2019==== [[File:Marc Pugh 17-03-2015 2.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Pugh playing for [[AFC Bournemouth]] in 2015]] He formed an effective partnership with fellow winger [[Ryan Fraser]]{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Mitchell |title=AFC Bournemouth: Versatile wing men can cause problems says Marc Pugh |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/10747216.AFC_Bournemouth__Versatile_wing_men_can_cause_problems_says_Pugh/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=18 October 2013 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} as Bournemouth enjoyed their best start to a season in the second tier in [[2013–14 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2013–14]].{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=AFC Bournemouth: Howe hoping Cherries can maintain best start |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/10687139.AFC_Bournemouth__Howe_hoping_Cherries_can_maintain_best_start/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=20 September 2013 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} In mid-November 2013 Pugh stated his belief that Bournemouth had made a "decent start" to the season; by this point he had scored 4 goals from 16 appearances.{{cite news |title=AFC Bournemouth: We've made a decent start says Marc Pugh |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/10801552.AFC_Bournemouth__We_ve_made_a_decent_start_says_Pugh/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=12 November 2013 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} He believed his playing intelligence improved by playing against more attack-minded [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|full back]]s in the Championship, saying that "They are still quick to react and you have got to use your brain a little bit more than in League One. It's developed me as a player because you need to learn how to perform in different situations against different players".{{cite news |first=Ned |last=Payne |title=AFC Bournemouth winger Pugh: You have to use your brain more in the Championship |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/11153599.AFC_Bournemouth_winger_Pugh__You_have_to_use_your_brain_more_in_the_Championship/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=17 April 2014 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} Pugh made 45 appearances and scored 5 goals in 2013–14 as Bournemouth finished in 10th place in the Championship,{{cite web |title=Championship: 2013/14: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=1305 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=3 June 2017}} which at the time was the highest league ranking in the club's history.{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Mitchell |title=AFC Bournemouth: Record-breaking Cherries have rewritten history in 2014 |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/11694403.AFC_Bournemouth__Record_breaking_Cherries_have_rewritten_history_in_2014/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=31 December 2014 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} In Bournemouth's first match of [[2014–15 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2014–15]], a 4–0 away win over Huddersfield on 9 August 2014, Pugh opened the scoring after only 26 seconds{{cite news |title=Huddersfield 0–4 Bournemouth |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28646430 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2014 |accessdate=1 March 2017}} with a composed finish from [[Matt Ritchie]]'s cross.{{cite news |first=Ned |last=Payne |title=AFC Bournemouth: Cherries ease to opening day triumph over Terriers |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/11399702.AFC_Bournemouth__Cherries_ease_to_opening_day_triumph/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=9 August 2014 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} On 25 October 2014, Pugh played as Bournemouth beat [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] 8–0 away to set a club record win,{{cite news |title=Birmingham 0–8 Bournemouth |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29669693 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2014 |accessdate=1 March 2017}} in which he scored the first [[Hat-trick#Association football|hat-trick]] of his career in the second half.{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=AFC Bournemouth star Marc Pugh: Hat-trick was for my family |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/11560192.AFC_Bournemouth_star_Marc_Pugh__Hat_trick_was_for_my_family/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=26 October 2014 |accessdate=16 December 2015}} Pugh and full-back [[Charlie Daniels (footballer)|Charlie Daniels]] formed a partnership on the left-hand side of the pitch during 2014–15, the duo starting all matches but one of a 14-match unbeaten run for Bournemouth.{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Mitchell |title=AFC Bournemouth ace Charlie Daniels: Cafu and Roberto Carlos changed full-back role forever |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/11712625.AFC_Bournemouth_ace_Charlie_Daniels__Cafu_and_Roberto_Carlos_changed_full_back_role_forever/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=9 January 2015 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} He scored the first goal in a 3–0 win over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 27 April 2015 with a left-footed shot into the top corner; this result all but sealed Bournemouth's promotion into the [[Premier League]].{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Match report: Jubilant scenes as Cherries effectively seal promotion against Bolton |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/12916967.MATCH_REPORT__Jubilant_scenes_as_Cherries_effectively_seal_promotion_against_Bolton/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=27 April 2015 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} He played in a 3–0 away win against Charlton on 2 May 2015, which confirmed promotion and, thanks to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] drawing their last match, the Championship title.{{cite news |title=Video: AFC Bournemouth: Cherries crowned champions of the Football League |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/12928675.VIDEO__AFC_Bournemouth__Cherries_crowned_champions_of_the_Football_League/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=2 May 2015 |accessdate=25 December 2015}} This was the first time Bournemouth had been promoted into the top flight in the club's 125-year history.{{cite news |title=Bournemouth: The minnows who made the Premier League |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32417417 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2015 |accessdate=1 March 2017}} Pugh was one of Bournemouth's most consistent players in 2014–15,{{cite news |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=AFC Bournemouth boss Eddie Howe: Marc Pugh has added real intelligence |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/11770959.AFC_Bournemouth_boss_Eddie_Howe__Marc_Pugh_has_added_real_intelligence/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=4 February 2015 |accessdate=26 December 2015}} and contributed with 9 goals from 44 matches. Pugh scored his first Premier League goal in Bournemouth's 4–3 away win over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 22 August 2015, with a curling shot past [[Darren Randolph]] in the 66th minute.{{cite news |first=Jacob |last=Steinberg |title=Bournemouth win thriller at West Ham with Callum Wilson hat-trick |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/22/west-ham-united-bournemouth-premier-league-match-report |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=22 August 2015 |accessdate=24 August 2015}} This goal meant he had scored in each of the top five divisions of the [[English football league system]].{{cite news |title=Premier League: 10 talking points from this weekend's action |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2015/aug/24/premier-league-10-talking-points-weekend-action |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=24 August 2015 |accessdate=24 August 2015}} In November 2015, Pugh signed a new two-and-a-half-year contract with Bournemouth, tying him to the club until the summer of 2018.{{cite news |first=Andy |last=Mitchell |title=AFC Bournemouth: Marc Pugh pens new two-and-a-half-year contract |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/14097616.AFC_Bournemouth__Marc_Pugh_pens_new_two_and_a_half_year_contract/ |newspaper=Bournemouth Daily Echo |date=23 November 2015 |accessdate=27 December 2015}} ====Hull City (loan)==== Pugh joined Championship club [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on 22 January 2019 on loan until the end of the [[2018–19 Hull City A.F.C. season|2018–19 season]], having made only three appearances for Bournemouth that season, all in cup competitions.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46965680 |title=Marc Pugh: Hull City sign midfielder on loan from Bournemouth |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 January 2019 |accessdate=23 January 2019}} He made his debut on 26 January as 66th-minute substitute in a 3–0 defeat away to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] when he replaced [[Kamil Grosicki]]. Pugh scored his first goal for Hull on 26 February 2019, in a home match against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] that City won 2–1.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47287437 | title = Hull City 2–1 Millwall | date = 26 February 2019 | work = BBC Sport | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 26 February 2019}} ==Style of play== Pugh primarily plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] but can also play as an [[attacking midfielder]].{{cite web |title=Player Details: Name: Marc Pugh |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/player/7764/marc-pugh |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=16 December 2015}} He has been noted for his dribbling skills and his ability to get past opposition players, and in February 2015 was praised by manager Eddie Howe for adding "real intelligence with his movement". ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 16 March 2019.}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club {{Infobox football biography | name = Aaron Ramsdale | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Aaron Christopher Ramsdale{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127 |title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=3 September 2018 |accessdate=4 September 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1998|5|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Chesterton, Staffordshire|Chesterton]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|ftin|order=flip}} | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[AFC Wimbledon]]
(on loan from [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]) | clubnumber = 35 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] | youthyears2 = {{0|0000}}–2016 | youthclubs2 = [[Sheffield United F.C. Academy|Sheffield United]] | years1 = 2016–2017 | clubs1 = [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2017– | clubs2 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018 | clubs3 = → [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] (loan) | caps3 = 19 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2019– | clubs4 = → [[AFC Wimbledon]] (loan) | caps4 = 13 | goals4 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2016 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2016–2017 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 12 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2017– | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2018– | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 1 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | medaltemplates = | club-update = 21:31, 23 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 12:32, 5 September 2018 (UTC) }} '''Aaron Christopher Ramsdale''' is an English [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[AFC Wimbledon]] on loan from [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. ==Club career== Born and raised in [[Chesterton, Staffordshire|Chesterton]], [[Staffordshire]] Ramsdale joined [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] but he was released at 15, due to being small at the time.{{cite news|title=AFC Bournemouth: Jussi Jaaskelainen inspired Aaron Ramsdale's rise to the top flight|url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/15095962.AFC_Bournemouth__Jaaskelainen_inspired_Ramsdale__39_s_rise_to_the_top_flight/|publisher=Bournemouth Echo|date=16 February 2017|accessdate=1 February 2018}} After being released by Bolton Wanderers, he joined [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] in 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2014/august/development-squad/|title=Development Squad|publisher=Sheffield United F.C.|date=1 August 2014|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201200046/https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2014/august/development-squad/|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} After graduating from [[Sheffield United F.C. Academy|Sheffield United's youth academy]], Ramsdale signed a scholarship with the club in May 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2014/may/welcome-to-the-new-scholars/|title=Welcome to the new scholars|publisher=Sheffield United F.C.|date=8 May 2014|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201200607/https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2014/may/welcome-to-the-new-scholars/|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} Ramsdale appeared twice as an unused substitute during the 2015–16 season against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] and [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]].{{cite news|title=Coventry City 3 – 1 Sheffield United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36118188|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 April 2016|accessdate=1 February 2018}}
{{cite news|title=Sheffield United 0 – 2 Scunthorpe United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36180664|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 May 2016|accessdate=1 February 2018}} In May 2016, he signed his first professional contract with the club.{{cite web|url=https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2016/may/professional-deals-for-youngsters/|title=Professional deals for youngsters|publisher=Sheffield United F.C.|date=6 May 2016|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201202123/https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2016/may/professional-deals-for-youngsters/|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} Ramsdale made his professional début starting in a 6–0 home victory over [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] in the [[FA Cup]], keeping a clean-sheet in the process.{{cite news|title=Sheffield United: Selfless George Long catches Blades boss Chris Wilder's eye|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/football/sheffield-united/sheffield-united-selfless-george-long-catches-blades-boss-chris-wilder-s-eye-1-8222245|accessdate=4 December 2016|publisher=Sheffield Star|date=7 November 2016}} He also made another appearance in the FA Cup against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] but lost 3–2.{{cite news|title=Bolton Wanderers 3 – 2 Sheffield United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38120945|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 December 2016|accessdate=1 February 2018}} ===A.F.C. Bournemouth=== On 31 January 2017, he was signed by [[Premier League]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for an undisclosed fee believed to be in the region of £800,000.{{cite news|title=AFC Bournemouth sign young 'keeper Aaron Ramsdale from Sheffield United|url=http://www.afcb.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/afc-bournemouth-keeper-aaron-ramsdale-from-sheffield-united-3547589.aspx|date=31 January 2017|accessdate=11 February 2017|publisher=A.F.C. Bournemouth|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201214616/http://www.afcb.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/afc-bournemouth-keeper-aaron-ramsdale-from-sheffield-united-3547589.aspx|archivedate=1 February 2017|deadurl=yes}} However, the move was reported to cost £1 million.{{cite news|title=Sheffield United: Blades manager Chris Wilder explains why Aaron Ramsdale was allowed to depart|url=https://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/football/sheffield-united/sheffield-united-blades-manager-chris-wilder-explains-why-aaron-ramsdale-was-allowed-to-depart-1-8364033|publisher=The Star|date=1 February 2017|accessdate=1 February 2018}} Ramsdale was on the bench for the final game of the 2016–17 season against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].{{cite news|title=Leicester City 1 – 1 AFC Bournemouth|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39912024|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 May 2017|accessdate=1 February 2018}} ====Chesterfield (loan)==== In the January transfer window, Ramsdale was loaned out to [[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] for the rest of the 2017–18 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.chesterfield-fc.co.uk/news/2018/january/20180105-fourth-new-recruit-joins-spireites/|title=Fourth New Recruit Joins Spireites|publisher=Chesterfield F.C.|date=5 January 2018|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201212800/https://www.chesterfield-fc.co.uk/news/2018/january/20180105-fourth-new-recruit-joins-spireites/|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} Ramsdale made his Chesterfield debut against [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] on 6 January 2018, but scored an own goal after he ''"allowed a seemingly harmless [[Kayden Jackson|Jackson]] strike from the right to squirm into the net"'', in a 4–0 loss.{{cite news|title=Accrington Stanley 4 – 0 Chesterfield|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42519872|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 January 2018|accessdate=1 February 2018}} In a follow-up match against [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] on 13 January 2018, he kept a clean sheet, in a 2–0 win.{{cite news|title=Chesterfield 2 – 0 Luton Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42587767|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 January 2018|accessdate=1 February 2018}} ====AFC Wimbledon (loan)==== On 4 January 2019, Ramsdale joined [[AFC Wimbledon]] on loan until the end of the 2018–19 season. {{cite web|url=https://www.afcwimbledon.co.uk/news/2019/january/dons-sign-goalkeeper-on-loan-from-bournemouth/|title=Dons sign goalkeeper on loan from Bournemouth|website=www.afcwimbledon.co.uk|date=4 January 2019}} The next day, Ramsdale made his debut for the Dons in a 3–2 Third Round FA Cup victory over [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]] at [[Highbury Stadium (Fleetwood)|Highbury Stadium]]. {{cite web|url=https://www.afcwimbledon.co.uk/news/2019/january/dons-march-into-fourth-round-with-a-dramatic-winner/|title=Dons march into fourth round with a dramatic winner|website=www.afcwimbledon.co.uk|date=5 January 2019}} His league debut came a week later in a 1–1 draw with [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] at the [[Ricoh Arena|Ricoh Arena]]. {{citeweb|url=https://www.afcwimbledon.co.uk/fixtures/first-team/201819/january/coventry-city-vs-afc-wimbledon-on-12-jan-19/#|title=Dons earn a creditable draw at Coventry|website=www.afcwimbledon.co.uk|date=12 January 2019}} ==International career== Ramsdale has represented England at [[England national under-18 football team|Under 18]], [[England national under-19 football team|Under 19]], [[England national under-20 football team|Under 20]] and [[England national under-21 football team|Under 21]] level.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players?p=357107|title=Profile – Aaron Ramdale|work=The Football Association|accessdate=13 March 2017}} He was first called up by England U18 in March 2016, where he made his debut on his debut for the side, in a 4–1 win over [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland U18]] on 27 March 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2016/march/call-up-for-young-keeper/|title=Call-up for young keeper|publisher=Sheffield United F.C.|date=16 March 2016|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201202427/https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2016/march/call-up-for-young-keeper/|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} He went on to make two appearances for the England U18 side. In August 2016, Ramsdale was called up by England U19, where he made his debut on 4 September 2016, in a 1–0 loss against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium U19]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2016/august/ramsdale-called-up/|title=Ramsdale called-up|publisher=Sheffield United F.C.|date=24 August 2016|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201203304/https://www.sufc.co.uk/news/2016/august/ramsdale-called-up/|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} Ramsdale started all five games for the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19]] side that won the [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]].{{cite web|title=European Under-19 Championship: England beat Portugal in final|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40619862|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 July 2017|accessdate=9 August 2017}}
{{cite news|title=Chelsea crucial to England winning U19 European Championship – Ramsdale|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/england-u19/story/3158799/chelsea-crucial-to-england-winning-u19-european-championship-aaron-ramsdale|publisher=ESPN|date=16 July 2017|accessdate=1 February 2018}} During the tournament, Ramsdale kept three clean sheets in five matches.{{cite web|url=https://www.afcb.co.uk/news/first-team/ramsdales-england-u19s-make-euros-final|title=RAMSDALE'S ENGLAND U19S MAKE EUROS FINAL|publisher=AFC Bournemouth|date=12 July 2017|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201205538/https://www.afcb.co.uk/news/first-team/ramsdales-england-u19s-make-euros-final|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} After winning the UEFA European U19-Championship, Ramsdale was called up by England U20 in August 2017, where he made his debut on 4 September 2017, in a 0–0 draw against [[Switzerland national football team|Switerzland U20]].{{cite web|url=https://www.afcb.co.uk/news/club-news/players-set-for-international-action|title=PLAYERS SET FOR INTERNATIONAL ACTION|publisher=AFC Bournemouth|date=29 August 2017|accessdate=1 February 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180201205844/https://www.afcb.co.uk/news/club-news/players-set-for-international-action|archivedate=1 February 2018|deadurl=no}} On 18 May 2018, Ramsdale received a call up to [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]]s for the first time by Manager [[Adrian Boothroyd]], for the [[Toulon Tournament]] with Englands group containing fixtures against [[Qatar national under-20 football team|Qatar U21]]s, China U21s and [[Mexico national under-20 football team|Mexico U21]]s.{{citenews|publisher=FA.COM|date=18 May 2018|accessdate=18 May 2018|title=ENGLAND U21S HEAD TO MAURICE REVELLO TOURNAMENT IN TOULON WITH A 20-MAN SQUAD |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2018/may/18/england-u21s-squad-named-for-toulon-180518}} Ramsdale made his first cap for the England u21 squad on 1st June 2018, playing the full 90 minutes in a 4–0 win against Qatar. ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 23 March 2019}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !colspan="3"|League !colspan="2"|[[FA Cup]] !colspan="2"|[[EFL Cup|League Cup]] !colspan="2"|Other !colspan="2"|Total |- Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] |[[2017–18 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|91150|2017|accessdate=9 January 2018}} |[[Premier League]] |0||0||0||0||0||0||colspan="2"|–||0||0 |- |[[Chesterfield F.C.|Chesterfield]] (loan) |[[2017–18 Chesterfield F.C. season|2017–18]] |[[EFL League Two|League Two]] |19||0||0||0||0||0||0||0||19||0 |- |[[AFC Wimbledon|AFC Wimbledon]] |[[2018-19 AFC Wimbledon season|2018–19]]{{soccerbase season|91150|2018|accessdate=6 January 2019}} |[[EFL League One|League One]] |13||0||3||0||0||0||0||0||16||0 |- !colspan="3"|Career total !32!!0!!5!!0!!0!!0!!0!!0!!37!!0 |} {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==Honours== ===International=== ; England U19 * [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship]]: [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2017]] ; England U21 * [[Toulon Tournament]]: [[2018 Toulon Tournament|2018]]{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2018/jun/09/engvmextoulon090618 |title=FINAL FIGHTBACK TAKES ENGLAND U21S TO TOULON HAT-TRICK WITH WIN OVER MEXICO |publisher=The FA |date=9 June 2018 |accessdate=17 March 2019}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Soccerbase}} {{AFC Wimbledon squad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ramsdale, Aaron}} [[Category:1998 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Stoke-on-Trent]] [[Category:English footballers]] [[Category:Association football goalkeepers]] [[Category:Bolton Wanderers F.C. players]] [[Category:Sheffield United F.C. players]] [[Category:A.F.C.
