Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] | caps4 = 17 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2019– | clubs5 = → [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] (loan) | caps5 = 8 | goals5 = 1 | club-update = 20:39, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = }} '''Tyrone Deon Mings''' (born 13 March 1993) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left-back]] or a [[Defender (association football)#centre-back|centre-back]] for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], on loan from [[A.F.C. Bournemouth| Bournemouth]].
==Club career==
===Early career=== Born in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], [[Avon (county)|Avon]], to former non-league striker Adie Mings, Mings joined [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2001 as an eight-year-old, but was released in 2009 when the youth budget was axed.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.thisiswiltshire.co.uk/sport/8299798.FOOTBALL__Youngster_Mings_aims_for_England/ | publisher =This Is Wiltshire | accessdate =5 May 2013 | date = 29 July 2010 | title = Football: Youngster Mings aims for England}}</ref> After leaving Southampton, he attended [[Millfield]] school for two years on a football scholarship. After leaving school, Mings signed for non-league side [[Yate Town F.C.|Yate Town]]. In the summer of 2012, he considered quitting football before eventually signing for his home town team [[Chippenham Town F.C.|Chippenham Town]].<ref name="stuartjames">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/dec/18/tyrone-mings-ipswich|title=Tyrone Mings makes his mark at Ipswich on and off the pitch|author=Stuart James|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
===Ipswich Town=== Mings signed for [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in 2013 after a short trial for a fee of [[Pound sterling|£]]10,000 and an agreement for Ipswich to play a pre-season game against Chippenham.<ref name="stuartjames"/> <ref name="auto1">{{Cite web | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22320506 | publisher = BBC Sport | accessdate =4 May 2013 | date = 4 May 2013 | title = Burnley 2–0 Ipswich}}</ref> On 4 May 2013, Mings made his debut for Ipswich on the last day of the [[2012–13 Ipswich Town F.C. season|2012–13 season]] against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref name="auto1"/> He went on into the [[2013–14 Ipswich Town F.C. season|2013–14 season]] starting two more games due to the suspension of [[Aaron Cresswell]]. On 4 January 2014, Mings started an FA Cup tie against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] at right back instead of his usual left back role.
Following [[Aaron Cresswell]]'s transfer to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], Mings was handed the number 3 shirt. Because of this, Mings offered to purchase new shirts for two fans who had bought shirts with his old number 15 printed on the back.<ref name="auto"/>
On transfer deadline day summer 2014, Mings was subject to a £3 million pound bid from [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] which was rejected by Ipswich. On 20 September 2014, Mings signed a new three-year contract with Ipswich.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29294717|title=BBC Sport – Tyrone Mings: Ipswich Town defender signs new contract|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 10 October 2014, Mings won the Sky Bet Championship Player of the Month Award for September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/2014/20141009sepchampionshippotmrp-2007954.aspx|title=Ipswich Town full-back Tyrone Mings named Sky Bet Championship Player of the Month|author=The Football League|work=football-league.co.uk}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 26 June 2015, Mings signed for newly promoted [[Premier League]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] on a four-year contract for an undisclosed fee, reported to be £8 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33293441|title=Bournemouth sign defender Tyrone Mings from Ipswich for £8m|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 June 2015|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>
Mings made his Premier League debut for Bournemouth on 29 August 2015 in a 1–1 draw with [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. However, he suffered a knee injury six minutes after coming on as a half-time substitute.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34025389|title=Bournemouth 1–1 Leicester|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2015|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> On 3 September 2015, it was confirmed that Mings' injury would mean that he would be sidelined for between 9 and 12 months.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34148465|title=Tyrone Mings: Bournemouth left-back's season over|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 September 2015|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> He made his comeback in a 3–0 defeat to [[Millwall F.C|Millwall]] in the third round of the [[2016–17 FA Cup|FA Cup]] on 7 January 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/08/bournemouth-eddie-howe-jordon-ibe-fa-cup-millwall-third-round|title=Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe calls Jordon Ibe a 'disappointment'|last=MacInnes|first=Paul|date=9 January 2017|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=9 January 2017}}</ref>
On 8 March 2017, Mings was banned by [[The Football Association|the FA]] for five matches following an alleged stamp on [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] in a match against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on the previous weekend.<ref>{{cite web|title=Man United 1 Bournemouth 1|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/38604380|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 March 2017|date=4 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tyrone Mings: Bournemouth defender to serve five-match ban|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39210644|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 March 2017|date=8 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=James|first1=Stuart|title=Anger at Bournemouth as Tyrone Mings gets five-match ban for violent conduct|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/08/bournemouth-defender-tyrone-mings-to-serve-five-match-ban|accessdate=10 March 2017|work=The Guardian|date=8 March 2017}}</ref>
====Aston Villa (loan)==== On 31 January 2019, Mings joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on loan for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Transfer news: Tyrone Mings joins Aston Villa |url=https://www.avfc.co.uk/News/2019/01/31/transfer-news-tyrone-mings-joins-aston-villa |accessdate=31 January 2019 |work=Aston Villa F.C. |date=31 January 2019}}</ref> He made his Villa debut on 2 February against [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]. The match was the subject of controversy following an incident where Mings stepped on the face of Reading forward [[Nélson Oliveira]] after a tussle for the ball. Oliveira was forced off with deep gashes to his forehead and nose.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ref Watch: Dermot Gallagher ponders whether Tyrone Mings deliberately stamped on Nelson Oliveira? |first=Dermot |last=Gallagher |publisher=Sky Sports |date=4 February 2019 |accessdate=4 February 2019 |url= https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/11627731/ref-watch-dermot-gallagher-ponders-whether-tyrone-mings-deliberately-stamped-on-nelson-oliveira}}</ref><ref name=medical>{{Cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/football-league/nelson-oliveira-tyrone-mings-stamp-face-watch-video-wife-instagram-aston-villa-reading-a8763056.html|title=Nelson Oliveira thanks medical staff for treatment on facial injuries as wife demands ban for Tyrone Mings |work=[[The Independent]] |date=4 February 2019 |accessdate=26 February 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= https://metro.co.uk/2019/02/07/reading-release-shocking-new-footage-tyrone-mings-stamp-nelson-oliveira-8470189/amp/|title=Reading release shocking new footage of Tyrone Mings’ stamp on Nelson Oliveira |work=Metro.co.uk |date=7 February 2019 |accessdate=26 February 2019 }}</ref> Mings later apologised, insisting that it was not intentional.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tyrone Mings sends message to Nelson Oliveira after horrific stamp |work=Metro.co.uk |date=3 February 2019 |accessdate=4 February 2019 |url= https://metro.co.uk/2019/02/03/tyrone-mings-sends-message-nelson-oliveira-horrific-stamp-reading-star-8430745/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/8339467/tyrone-mings-stamp-readings-oliveira-blood/|title=Tyrone Mings apologises after brutal stamp on Reading’s Oliveira leaves face streaming with blood |work=The Sun |date=3 February 2019 |accessdate=26 February 2019 }}</ref> As referee Geoff Eltringham had seen the incident and determined that it was accidental, no retrospective action was taken.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tyrone Mings: Aston Villa defender will not face action over Nelson Oliveira incident |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 February 2019 |accessdate=4 February 2019 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47119805}}</ref>
Mings scored his first Aston Villa goal in his second game, on 8 February 2019. He scored in the 82nd minute of the home game against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]. At that point, Aston Villa had been losing 3–0, but they went on to complete a late comeback to draw the game 3–3.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47083170|title=Villa come from 3-0 down to deny Sheff Utd top spot|last=|first=|date=8 February 2019|work=[[BBC Sport]]|access-date=9 February 2019}}</ref>
==Personal life== Mings is the son of Adie Mings, a former striker with non-league [[Bath City F.C.|Bath City]] and [[Gloucester City A.F.C.|Gloucester City]] who currently works as a scout for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/arsenal/11277314/Tyrone-Mings-transfer-Why-Chelsea-hold-an-unusual-advantage-over-Arsenal.html|title=Tyrone Mings transfer: Why Chelsea hold an unusual advantage over Arsenal|date=6 December 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> His father was assistant manager then manager at Chippenham Town, but became director of football shortly before Tyrone joined the club.
Off the field, Mings has gained a reputation for charitable and generous acts.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.twtd.co.uk/ipswich-town-news/22662/supporters-club-praise-for-generous-mings | publisher = twtd.co.uk | accessdate =26 December 2013 | date = 17 March 2013 | title = Supporters Club Praise for Generous Mings}}</ref> He spent Christmas Day 2013 feeding homeless people<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.twtd.co.uk/ipswich-town-news/24276/mings-spends-christmas-day-feeding-homeless | publisher = twtd.co.uk | accessdate =26 December 2013 | date = 26 December 2013 | title = Mings Spends Christmas Day Feeding Homeless}}</ref> and when he was given the number 3 shirt by Ipswich at the beginning of the [[2014–15 Ipswich Town F.C. season|2014–15 season]], he replaced the shirts of fans who had already bought ones with his old number on the back.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-suffolk-28416351|title=Footballer Tyrone Mings vows 'to buy shirts for fans'|publisher=BBC News|date=22 July 2014}}</ref>
Outside of football, Mings has a business interest in an interior design company in Bournemouth.<ref>{{Cite web | url =http://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/15013542.The_designer_and_the_Cherries_star_bringing_luxury_to_Bournemouth___s_homes/ | publisher = dorsetecho.co.uk | accessdate =26 September 2017 | date = 15 January 2017 | title = KTM Design's Katie Thomas on the business she's set up with AFC Bournemouth player Tyrone Mings}}</ref>
==International career== As well as being eligible for [[England national football team|England]], Mings is also eligible for [[Barbados national football team|Barbados]] through his paternal grandparents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.twtd.co.uk/ipswich-town-news/23976/mings-could-be-towns-first-barbados-international/on-this-day|title=Mings Could Be Town's First Barbados International - Ipswich Town News|publisher=}}</ref> His father Adie turned down a call-up from Barbados during his own playing career.<ref>https://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/news/15675312.mings-would-potentially-consider-representing-barbados/</ref>
==Career statistics== {{updated|16 March 2019}}<ref>{{soccerbase|id=69420|name=Tyrone Mings|accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Connor Mahoney | image = | fullname = Connor Anthony Mahoney{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|2|12|df=y}}{{cite web |url=http://accringtonstanley.co.uk/player/connor-mahoney/ |title=Player profile: Connor Mahoney |publisher=Accrington Stanley F.C |accessdate=17 November 2013}} | birth_place = [[Blackburn]], England{{cite web |url=http://www.11v11.com/players/connor-mahoney-241176/ |title=Connor Mahoney |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=17 November 2013}} | height = {{convert|1.75|m|order=flip}} | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] / [[Forward (association football)#Winger|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]
(on loan from [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]]) | clubnumber = 7 | youthyears1 = {{0|000}} | youthclubs1 = [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] | youthyears2 = {{0|0000}}–2013 | youthclubs2 = [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] | youthyears3 = 2013–2014 | youthclubs3 = [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] | years1 = 2013 | clubs1 = [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] | caps1 = 4 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2013–2017 | clubs2 = [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] | caps2 = 16 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017– | clubs3 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] (loan) | caps4 = 4 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = → [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] (loan) | caps5 = 26 | goals5 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2014 | nationalteam1= [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2014 | nationalteam2= [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2017 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 17:19, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Connor Anthony Mahoney''' (born 12 February 1997) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a winger for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], on [[loan (sports)|loan]] from [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] of the [[Premier League]]. ==Career== Initially starting out at Burnley and Blackburn Rovers,{{cite news|title=Sky Sports Scout – Connor Mahoney|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/15198/9163001/sky-sports-scout-connor-mahoney|publisher=Sky Sports|date=21 May 2014|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Mahoney moved to [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]], where he progressed through the academy and began his career there.{{cite news|title=Accrington Stanley's footballing starlets are attracting attention from talent scouts|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/10724952.Accrington_Stanley___s_footballing_starlets_are_attracting_attention_from_talent_scouts/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=8 October 2013|accessdate=31 August 2017}} He then made his professional debut on 28 August 2013 in a 2–0 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] defeat against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].{{cite news |title=Accrington 0–2 Cardiff|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23776662|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 August 2013|accessdate=4 September 2013}} He then went on to make his league debut coming on as a substitute for [[Shay McCartan]] in the 1–0 home defeat to [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] on 31 August 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23853447|title=Accrington 0–1 Burton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 August 2013|accessdate=13 December 2013}} By the time of his departure from Accrington Stanley, Mahoney went on to make 6 appearances.{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers to sign Accrington Stanley star Mahoney|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/10867795.Blackburn_Rovers_to_sign_Accrington_Stanley_star_Mahoney/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=10 December 2013|accessdate=31 August 2017}} ===Blackburn Rovers=== Mahoney signed for [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 13 December 2013 and linked up with their development squad.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football-25366496|title=Blackburn Rovers sign Connor Mahoney from Accrington Stanley|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=13 December 2013}} He made an immediate impression and was given squad number 31 for the first team. He was an unused substitute in a 2–1 win against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] at [[Elland Road]] on 1 January 2014. [https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25512911 "Leeds United 1–2 Blackburn Rovers"] BBC Sport. 1 January 2014. Retrieved 15 January 2014. Mahoney made his competitive debut for Blackburn Rovers on 15 January against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in the [[FA Cup]], replacing [[Lee Williamson]] in the 89th minute of the match.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25647870 "Manchester City 5–0 Blackburn Rovers"] BBC Sport. 15 January 2014. Retrieved 15 January 2014. On 12 February 2014, he signed his first professional contract with the club.{{cite web|title=Birthday boy Connor signs pro|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/birthday-boy-connor-signs-pro-1359643.aspx|publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C.|accessdate=16 February 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225213140/http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/birthday-boy-connor-signs-pro-1359643.aspx|archivedate=31 August 2017|deadurl=yes}} Following this, Mahoney would spend the next two seasons at the club's reserve, where he developed along the way.{{cite news|title=Who will be the next Blackburn Rovers youngster to break through?|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/12960494.Who_will_be_the_next_Blackburn_Rovers_youngster_to_break_through_/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=20 May 2015|accessdate=31 August 2017}}{{cite news|title=Youngster Connor Mahoney edging back into first-team picture at Blackburn Rovers|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/13785117.Youngster_Connor_Mahoney_edging_back_into_first_team_picture_at_Blackburn_Rovers/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=26 September 2015|accessdate=31 August 2017}} After making no first team appearances in the 2014–15 season, Mahoney said he's making his way to make a breakthrough in the first team for the 2015–16 season.{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers youngster Connor Mahoney determined to force his way into first team|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/13800620.Blackburn_Rovers_youngster_Connor_Mahoney_determined_to_force_his_way_into_first_team/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=3 October 2015|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Having played in the reserve side throughout the 2015–16 season,{{cite news|title='He's got a chance' – Paul Lambert reckons Connor Mahoney can become a Blackburn Rovers regular|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/14440621._He_s_got_a_chance____Paul_Lambert_reckons_Connor_Mahoney_can_become_a_Blackburn_Rovers_regular/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=21 April 2016|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Mahoney made his first Blackburn Rovers' appearances in two years, where he started and played 71 minutes before being substituted, in a 1–1 draw against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 19 April 2016.{{cite news|title=Nottingham Forest 1 – 1 Blackburn Rovers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36021247|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 April 2016|accessdate=31 August 2017}} He also made another appearance, in the follow up match, in a 2–2 draw against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers 2 – 2 Bristol City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36060767|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 April 2016|accessdate=31 August 2017}} At the end of the 2015–16 season, he made 2 appearances for the side. In the 2016–17 season, Mahoney continued to remain in the reserve side at the start of the season, although he appeared twice as an unused substitute in late-August.{{cite news|title=Damien Johnson: Checkatrade Trophy 'perfect stage' for Blackburn Rovers youngsters|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/14711051.Damien_Johnson__Checkatrade_Trophy__perfect_stage__for_Blackburn_Rovers_youngsters/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=30 August 2016|accessdate=31 August 2017}} In late-December, Mahoney began to appear as an unused substitute in a number of games.{{cite news|title=FUTURE STARS: The ones to watch at Blackburn Rovers in 2017...|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/15011655.FUTURE_STARS__The_ones_to_watch_at_Blackburn_Rovers_in_2017___/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=10 January 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Mahoney remained at the club, despite some loan bids from League One clubs for him.{{cite news|title=Owen Coyle keen to keep Connor Mahoney in first team picture as Blackburn Rovers turn down loan bids|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/15023729.Owen_Coyle_keen_to_keep_Connor_Mahoney_in_first_team_picture_as_Blackburn_Rovers_turn_down_loan_bids/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=14 January 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} He then made his first appearance of the 2016–17 season, coming on as a second-half substitute, in a 1–0 win over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 4 February 2017.{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers 1 – 0 Queens Park Rangers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38778703|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 February 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Following this, Mahoney received a handful of first team appearances as Blackburn Rovers fought to survive relegation from the Championship.{{cite news|title=Owen Coyle keen to secure Connor Mahoney's long-term future at Blackburn Rovers but says talks in the hands of Paul Senior|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/15085890.Owen_Coyle_keen_to_secure_Connor_Mahoney_s_long_term_future_at_Blackburn_Rovers_but_says_talks_in_the_hands_of_Paul_Senior/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=11 February 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Then, he set up an equalising goal for [[Derrick Williams (footballer)|Derrick Williams]], in a 1–1 draw against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 7 March 2017.{{cite news|title=Blackburn Rovers 1 – 1 Cardiff City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39111417|publisher=BBC Sport|date=7 March 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} In the following match against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] four days later, he set up a goal for [[Lucas João]] in a 2–2 draw.{{cite news|title=Norwich City 2 – 2 Blackburn Rovers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39162733|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 March 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} On 14 April 2017, in a match against Nottingham Forest, Mahoney also set up a goal for [[Tommie Hoban]], who scored the only goal in the game.{{cite news|title=Nottingham Forest 0 – 1 Blackburn Rovers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39523090|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 April 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} By the end of the 2016–17 season, which saw Blackburn Rovers relegated to League One, he had made 21 appearances in all competitions. ===AFC Bournemouth=== Following Blackburn Rovers' relegation in summer 2017, Mahoney was offered a new contract by the club.{{cite news|title=Rovers release six first-team players but are looking to secure the future of Connor Mahoney|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/15295134.Rovers_release_six_first_team_players_but_are_looking_to_secure_the_future_of_Connor_Mahoney/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} However, he was also linked with moves away from the club, increasingly attracting interests from Nottingham Forest{{cite news|title=Connor Mahoney: Blackburn's Tony Mowbray expects Nottingham Forest move for winger|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40290745|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 June 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} and [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].{{cite news|title=Rovers raid? Celtic interested in out-of-contract Blackburn Rovers winger Connor Mahoney, according to reports in England|url=https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/football/1130961/celtic-interest-blackburn-rovers-connor-mahoney-reports/|newspaper=The Scottish Sun|date=15 June 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} It was reported that Mahoney turned down a contract extension at Blackburn Rovers and was set to leave the club.{{cite news|title=Connor Mahoney edging closer to Rovers exit|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/15331547.Connor_Mahoney_edging_closer_to_Rovers_exit/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=7 June 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} On 4 July 2017 Mahoney made a move to [[Premier League]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]], signing a four-year contract.{{cite news|title=Bournemouth sign Connor Mahoney on four-year deal after leaving Blackburn Rovers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40495709|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 July 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} After playing in two cup games for the Cherries in 2017, Connor moved to [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on loan for the second half of the 2017–18 season.{{cite web|title=Mahoney completes Barnsley loan move|url=https://www.afcb.co.uk/news/first-team/mahoney-completes-barnsley-loan-move|date=29 January 2018|accessdate=29 January 2018}} On 7 August 2018, Mahoney joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] on a season-long loan deal.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45098389 |title=Connor Mahoney: Birmingham City sign Bournemouth winger on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 August 2018 |accessdate=8 August 2018}} He made his debut as a second-half substitute in a 1–0 defeat away to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45066579 |title=Middlesbrough 1–0 Birmingham City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2018 |accessdate=11 August 2018}} Having started the match at home to [[Sheffield Wednesday]] on 27 October in place of the injured [[Jacques Maghoma]], Mahoney scored his first career goal just before half-time when he "cut in unchallenged from the left to fire in a right-footed shot past Cameron Dawson into the far roof of the net"; Birmingham went on to win 3–1.{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/birmham-vs-sheff-wed/392711 |title=Birmingham 3-1 Sheffield Wednesday: Blues keep up fine run |publisher=Sky Sports |date=27 October 2018 |accessdate=28 October 2018}} ==International career== In January 2014, he was called up by [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] for the first time.{{cite web|title=Connor gets England call|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/england-call-for-connor-1306783.aspx|publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C.|accessdate=21 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122052323/http://www.rovers.co.uk/news/article/england-call-for-connor-1306783.aspx|archivedate=31 August 2017|deadurl=yes}} Mahoney made his England U17 (and his only appearance for the side) debut, in a 2–1 loss against [[Belgium national under-17 football team|Belgium U17]] on 30 January 2014.{{cite news|title=ENGLAND U17S SUFFER CRUEL DEFEAT AGAINST BELGIUM|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2014/jan/30/england-u17s-v-belgium-match-report-300114|publisher=The Football Association|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Eight months later, in September 2014, Mahoney was called up by [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rovers.co.uk/news/2014/september/england-call-for-connor/|title=England call for Connor|publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C.|date=20 September 2014|accessdate=31 August 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831193534/https://www.rovers.co.uk/news/2014/september/england-call-for-connor/|archivedate=31 August 2017|deadurl=no}} Four days later, he made his England U18 debut, in a 2–0 loss against [[Italy national under-18 football team|Italy U18]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rovers.co.uk/news/2014/september/mahoney-plays-for-england/|title=Mahoney plays for England|publisher=Blackburn Rovers F.C.|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=31 August 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831193522/https://www.rovers.co.uk/news/2014/september/mahoney-plays-for-england/|archivedate=31 August 2017|deadurl=no}} ==Career statistics== [[Blackburn]], England, Mahoney attended [[Witton Park High School]].{{cite news|title=Blackburn's Witton Park honours its students for best ever GCSEs|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/10830517.Blackburn_s_Witton_Park_honours_its_students_for_best_ever_GCSEs/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=28 November 2013|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Mahoney grew up supporting Blackburn Rovers.{{cite news|title=Accrington Stanley boss couldn't block Mahoney's Blackburn Rovers move|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/10875865.Accrington_Stanley_boss_couldn_t_block_Mahoney_s_Blackburn_Rovers_move/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=13 December 2013|accessdate=31 August 2017}} His brother Dom is also a footballer.{{cite news|title=Family ties at Nelson|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/11251970.Family_ties_at_Nelson/|newspaper=The Lancashire Telegraph|date=3 June 2014|accessdate=31 August 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}}
